The stock has been whipsawing in-and-out of the 5% buy range over the last several trading sessions. On the downside, Essent Group (ESNT) fell 4% on heavy volume. The stock had gained as much as 18% from the 28.66 entry, but today's drop suggests a change in direction.FANG stocks appeared to be gaining some momentum as they outperformed the Nasdaq. Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX), and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) all led the way in the stock market today.Facebook gained 2.3% in above-average volume and looked to reclaim its 200-day moving average, which it has not held since the end of November. The stock's volume profile has improved in recent days; the up days are on higher volume than the down days.Amazon increased 2.4%, but stopped just short of its 50-day moving average. The 792 price area has acted as resistance over the last month.Netflix, a SwingTrader member, tacked on 1.3% and is approaching a large cup-with-handle buy point at 129.39. The video-streaming company has held up better than other large-cap tech stocks in the current environment and is working on a fifth consecutive up week, which would be considered a sign of institutional accumulation.Alphabet rose 1.5% and is approaching a cup buy point at 839.10. Although the stock is near new highs, its Relative Price Strength Rating is a dismal 47.Fellow large cap tech stock, Apple (AAPL) gained 2% following news that the company will begin selling its AirPods wireless headphones after a two-month delay that put a damper on holiday sales. The AirPods will be available for $159. The stock regained its 50-day moving average late last week and is approaching a 118.79 flat-base entry.RELATED:5 Factors That Could Drive Apple Stock Higher In 2017: CitiAlphabet Said Scaling Back Ambitions To Make Self-Driving CarsFacebook's Instagram Brings Live Video Feature To All U.S. Users

For the second time in 10 years, the Fed is poised to deliver an upward move in its target interest rate this week. The probability of a rate hike on Dec. 14 has risen to over 97%, according to much-watched CME Fed Funds futures.Consistent U.S. employment growth, coupled with improved housing figures, solid retail sales, rising consumer confidence and increased industrial production, have led Fed officials to prep markets for this long-awaited change.The positive data has fallen within the context of persistent anemic GDP growth, suppressed business investment/capital spending, and weak bank lending. Critical global events — Greek default, Chinese economic stress, emerging market weakness, commodity decline, Brexit, and the U.S. presidential election — had provided markets and central bankers reason to be cautious in 2016.Nevertheless, optimism over a lower regulatory burden and the tax stimulus expected under a Trump presidency has buoyed equity markets. The Fed clearly has the green light for a modest move, possibly more.What's important now is the likely pace of Fed action given economic data that might trigger them to proceed more, or less, aggressively. With so much interest in the Fed's thinking, three measures stand out as being critical:The output gap:  The difference between what the U.S. could potentially produce and what it is currently producing, the so-called output gap, has kept a lid on inflation pressures.The Fed's calculation of capacity utilization stands at 75.3%, significantly higher than the 66.7% that it hit in 2009, but still below the average of the past 45 years, 80%. The gap has, arguably for years, allowed the Fed to delay rate hikes without fear of inflation.The labor force participation rate, moreover, an important component of potential output, is just 62.7%, well below the 66% prior to the recession and the 67% peak hit in the late 90s/early 2000s. Productivity of U.S. workers, another major component of potential output, has also slowed during the past decade.While there are demographic reasons likely contributing to the decline in participation, Chair Janet Yellen has stated that she believes a stable labor force participation rate will be a sign that the economy is absorbing people discouraged from work. After citing "underutilization" in their statements for months, the Fed dropped the reference in March 2016 in favor of pointing to strong labor market growth, a sign that they believe the measure has narrowed.Further decline of the output gap in the U.S., a modest increase in labor participation and improvements in productivity would signal that the Fed needs to adopt a more aggressive posture.'Velocity' of money: Economists recite the old English proverb: "You can lead a horse to water, but you can't make him drink."  If inflation is too much money chasing too few goods, then we won't have it without more money moving through the economy, which will require more lending by banks. After a steep recession, money velocity can dip as people pay down debts. It is expected to rise again as the economy moves into the later stages of recovery.The velocity of money, by its broadest measure Money with Zero Maturity (MZM), is maintaining all-time lows after years of this recovery, despite the Fed growing the monetary base in a massive way since 2009. After a minor increase following the recession, MZM velocity has declined for the past five years.The proverbial horse has been standing at the water's edge for years now, yet there's been little drinking. There are few signs that too much money is chasing too few goods: Banks are not lending out their rebuilt reserves and businesses are not spending or investing. A modest increase in velocity would signal a more normal economic expansion and compel the Fed to move more aggressively.Inflation expectations: While we hear quite a bit about the Fed's inflation target of 2%, and how we are not there yet, it is inflation expectations that often concern policymakers most. Keeping inflation expectations in check is a key barometer of whether the Fed is maintaining its credibility as an inflation fighter — whether markets believe the Fed will act prudently to maintain price stability. It is that credibility, in fact, that is the true currency of a central bank.Since Chairman Paul Volker broke inflation in the early 80s, the Fed has maintained credibility, and inflation expectations have come down dramatically, from over 6% to around 2% today.The economy can and often does experience temporary price rises, but if people believe these higher prices will not last, if their expectations are anchored, prices will eventually follow a more normal progression and avoid real economic harm. With inflation expectations anchored the way they appear to be today, the economy can continue to grow steadily.The five-year figure for inflation expectations is 2.07%, still anchored but up significantly from a July reading of 1.41. We can be sure the Fed has recognized the recent rise in this measure and it will lead to the Fed maintaining a more aggressive posture should it persist.There is a whiff of change in the air, particularly following the U.S. presidential election, and the optimism reflected in markets is sure to alter the Fed's considerations. A keen eye on these three measures — the presence or lack of presence of an output gap, the velocity of money, and inflation expectations — are likely to provide the clues to the pace at which the central bank will move in the months and years ahead.

Loading the player... Stocks presented another bullish session in the spirit of a Santa Claus rally. While the Russell 2000 almost played the role of Scrooge, finishing just a hair higher, most other gauges gained nicely Tuesday. The Nasdaq composite rallied 0.9%, ending not far from intraday highs, in posting an all-time high. Ditto that for the S&P 500, which…

U.S. stock indexes booked solid gains Wednesday afternoon, but biomed stocks dived on President-elect Donald Trump's vow to bring down drug prices.The Nasdaq advanced 0.7%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 1% and 1.4%, respectively. The small cap Russell 2000 rose 0.5%. Volume in the stock market today was running higher on both major exchanges.Medical stocks struggled after Trump said in a Time Magazine interview that he doesn't like "what's happened with drug prices" and would bring down prices. Trump made no mention of investment in research and development, which is never free. Companies such as Celgene (CELG) and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) put 40% of revenue into research and development, while Big Cap 20 stock Incyte (INCY) put 63% of revenue into R&D last year. Without strong growth in revenue and profits, R&D budgets would shrink, and the odds of developing new drugs would also fade.High-end biomeds, which rely the most on R&D, led the retreat Wednesday with the group down about 4%.Meanwhile, for the rest of the market it was business as usual.Bank stocks, which have led the Trump rally, were little changed. The exchange-traded fund PowerShares KBW Bank (KBWB) inched up 0.7% to 47.05. The bank ETF has gained about 21% since its Election Day close.Steel has been another area of strength in the stock market and that continued Wednesday afternoon. Gainers among steel producers included United States Steel (X), up 5.4%; AK Steel (AKS), up 3.7%; and Nucor (NUE), up 1.7%. Steel alloy stocks also showed strength. Carpenter Technology (CRS) popped 4.5% as it retook its 50-day line. Allegheny Technologies (ATI) rose 1% as it tried to clear a base.In economic news, the Labor Department's Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey was little changed in October. Layoffs slipped, but so did the rate of hiring. The job openings gauge is one that Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen watches closely. CME Group's FedWatch Tool was unchanged Wednesday with a 94.9% chance of an interest rate hike in December.RELATED:Trump Targets Drug Prices, Apple, Seeks '5 Minutes' With Offshoring Firms10 Chip Stocks Get Buy RatingsSouthwest Air, Delta Break Out Of Bases

U.S. stock indexes poked higher in mixed volume, after Fed chief Janet Yellen gave a clear indication of a rate hike "relatively soon" and vowed to serve a full term.The Nasdaq advanced 0.7%, while the S&P 500 rose 0.4%. The blue chip Dow Jones industrial average added 0.1%. Volume in the stock market today was running lower on the NYSE and higher on the Nasdaq.Yellen's term runs through January 2018. President-elect Donald Trump has talked both ways on Yellen. In May, he said he had "great respect" for Yellen. In September, he said Yellen is "very political" and "she should be ashamed of herself."Meanwhile, CME Group's FedWatch Tool pegs the chance for a December rate hike at 90.6%, unchanged from the previous day.Banks are expected to benefit from higher rates, and the bank stocks continued to show strength Thursday. The KBW Nasdaq Bank Index popped 1.6%. PowerShares KBW Bank Portfolio (KBWB), the exchange-traded fund that tracks the index, has risen almost 14% since the market's Election Day close. The ETF has 24 bank stocks in its portfolio with Bank of America (BAC) its biggest holding at 8.4%.In the S&P 500, Best Buy (BBY) was the day's best performer, up 11% in huge volume. The stock broke out Wednesday, clearing a 40.31 buy point. The consumer electronics retailer trounced the Street's views on earnings by 32%, according to William O'Neil + Co. data. Same-store sales also were stronger than expected.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, the homebuilder group was headed for a seventh consecutive daily gain. October housing starts came in strong, topping the consensus view by 13% and surpassing the highest estimate in the range by 9%.RELATED:Yellen Here To Stay; Rate Hike Coming 'Relatively Soon'Which Rebounded More, Stocks Or Home Prices?

Loading the player... U.S. stock indexes took a politically inspired hit Friday, as news broke that the FBI was investigating newly discovered emails from Hillary Clinton's personal email server. The Nasdaq settled with a 0.5% loss after being up 0.3%. The S&P 500 fell 0.3% while the Dow Jones industrial average edged down less than 0.1%. The IBD 50 rose 0.3%.…

Bears swatted the U.S. stock indexes lower midday Thursday with the catalysts open to question.The Nasdaq lopped off 0.7%, gaining back some ground after being down as much as 1.3%, while the S&P 500 and the blue chip Dow Jones industrial average matched that loss. The lone gainer was the Dow Jones utility average, up 1.3% in the stock market today.Volume rose on both exchanges vs. the same time on Wednesday, keeping to a recent trend of increasing on downward price action, which is a bearish pattern.What was driving the indexes lower? Some analysts pointed to weak data from China. Others said the likelihood of an interest-rate hike from the Federal Reserve continues to make the market uneasy.China's September exports fell 10% from the year-ago level, far weaker than the 3% drop expected. U.S. Steel (X) gapped down 6%, while specialty steel firm Carpenter Technology (CRS) gapped down 3%. Apart from the China factor, steel prices have dropped, putting additional pressure on steel firms.Meanwhile, a rate hike is looking more certain. CME Group's FedWatch Tool puts the chance of a rate hike by December at about 70%, up from 67% earlier in the week..IBD'S TAKE: Here is a savvy Way To Play Interest Rates, and it's not about investing in banks.Another factor that could be roiling the markets is the U.S. presidential election. A study by Sam Stovall of S&P Global Market Intelligence shows that the party that currently controls the White House wins if the S&P 500 rises from the end of July to the end of October. Right now, the gauge is down about 2.5%, which would suggest challenger Donald Trump will win. But this gauge has roughly two more weeks to run before it gives a conclusive reading. The accuracy of the gauge going back to 1944 is 86%.The years when the election indicator didn't work tended to be years when a strong third party was in the mix. This year the Libertarians and the Greens are threatening to pull amounts that could be pivotal on a state-by-state basis.Blue chips were mostly down. Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) was one of the few exceptions, up 1.4% in brisk volume. The blue chip retailer sank below its 200-day moving average on Oct. 7 in heavy volume, but the stock is just 9% below a 52-week high of 75.19.The stock has been sliding ever since a breakout in November 2014 ran out of gas. Watch for a new bottoming base to form.In the S&P 500, Freeport McMoRan (FCX) took the hardest hit, down 7% in twice its usual volume.Only eight stocks in the IBD 50 were up. The biggest loser was chip designer Silicon Motion Technology (SIMO), down 6% in heavy volume.RELATED:Which Sector Leading Stock Expects The Biggest EPS Gain?What To Watch For As Big Banks ReportMany Retailing Stocks Have Been Forming The Bottoming Base Pattern

Financial markets are beginning to believe the Federal Reserve.That's the simplest explanation for the tumble that major stock indexes took on Tuesday, which saw the 10-year Treasury yield rise to a four-month high and the U.S. dollar index hit its highest level in seven months.While the U.S. central bank's key overnight lending rate is barely above zero and policymakers have repeatedly reined in their intentions for further hikes, markets have taken each Fed pronouncement with a grain of salt. Whether investors doubted the Fed's resolve or its economic forecast, markets have been pricing in an even lower-rate future than the Fed has telegraphed. No longer — at least not to a significant extent.When the Fed's rate committee last met on Sept. 21, members' projections pointed to a hike in December and two rate hikes in 2017. Yet markets, while on board with the December hike, persisted in pricing in less than a 33% chance of a subsequent hike before the fourth quarter of 2017.But over the past seven trading sessions, which have seen the 10-year Treasury yield rise from 1.56% to 1.76%, investors have gotten with the Fed's program, so to speak. Now, markets are pricing in roughly a 46% chance of a rate hike in September 2017 (following an earlier hike this December), the CME Group's FedWatch tool shows.Here's why this is causing a simultaneous re-pricing of stocks in the short term:While the uptick in government bond yields might make stocks modestly less attractive on a relative basis, the bigger issue is likely the rise in the dollar against other major currencies as investors see the Fed tightening and other major central banks easing. The U.S. dollar index, which measures the greenback vs. a basket of major currencies, jumped to 97.7 on Tuesday, the highest since March 10, from 96.9 on Monday.That's a negative for the earnings of U.S. multinationals which get a sizable share of their sales and earnings in foreign currencies, such as Pfizer (PFE), Boeing (BA), Microsoft (MSFT) and Alphabet (GOOGL).Further, while other countries may be helped by weaker currencies, including eurozone nations and the U.K., economists believe the overall effect of a stronger dollar dampens global growth. That's especially true of emerging markets, which have high levels of dollar-denominated debt that becomes harder to service as the dollar rises.The surprise, if there is one, is that the rise in Treasury yields has come after a September jobs report showed a smaller-than-expected 156,000 gain. The explanation is that Fed policymakers think the U.S. has already reached full employment and that the economy only needs to create perhaps 100,000 jobs a month to keep the jobless rate steady.IBD'S TAKE: How can you tell if a jobs report is too hot, too cold or just right? Markets may react negatively or positively on the day of the report, but the key for investors is to stay abreast of the market's prevailing trend. Visit IBD University for a primer on how to time the stock market and read The Big Picture column every day.The good news is that the markets have come most of the way in adjusting to the Fed's timetable. Yet, the Fed has been pretty unreliable in its predictions, so markets may still need to adjust — one way or another — if policymakers turn out to be too optimistic or pessimistic when it comes to growth, inflation and the job market.RELATED:Divided Fed Holds Off On Rate Hike, Sees Slower Tightening PathU.S. Added So-So 156,000 Jobs In September, Won't Change Fed Dollar Dive On Fed Boosts Outlook For Exports, Corporate Profits

Loading the player... If your portfolio was flush with dairy and meat-product stocks, then Tuesday's action was likely mouthwatering. While shares in those two defensive industry groups rose, stocks in virtually the rest of IBD's 197 industry groups dropped fast, as the stock market encountered its roughest session of selling in more than a month. A late-afternoon rebound managed only…

Wall Street economists expect Friday's employment report to show that the economy added 190,000 jobs in September and the jobless rate held steady at 4.9%.August's 151,000 job gain was a step back from this year's monthly average growth of 181,500. Yet, because of the implications for Federal Reserve policy, markets are more nervous about an upside surprise than another subpar result.Treasury yields have been on the rise this week, with the 10-year yield rising close to a four-month high on Wednesday amid stronger ISM reports on manufacturing and nonmanufacturing. As inflation creeps closer to the Fed's 2% target, the risk is that stronger-than-expected job growth and wage gains will lead markets to price in a somewhat faster pace of rate hikes in 2017.On the other hand, even a weak jobs report is unlikely to shift the Federal Reserve's December timetable for hiking its key interest rate.There are two reasons a December hike is pretty much a done deal. First, as Dan North, chief economist at trade credit insurer Euler Hermes North America, puts it: "The Fed has painted itself into a corner, just like last year."Projections by 13 of 17 participants at the Fed's September 2015 meeting pointed to a rate hike before year end, and they followed through in December, even as the economy was slowing to first gear, as subsequent data confirmed.At the latest meeting, North notes that 14 of 17 participants saw a rate hike by year end. "Anybody smell any paint?"As of now, markets see about a 60% chance of a hike in December, but just a 40% chance of a subsequent hike before the fourth quarter of 2017, according to CME Group's FedWatch tool.The second reason that a weak jobs report won't shift Fed policy helps explain the first: Most Fed policymakers already think the U.S. is close to full employment — the point at which job gains only need to match the net additions to the workforce, or else wage and inflation pressures will intensify.IBD'S TAKE: How can you tell if a jobs report is too hot, too cold, or just right? Markets may react negatively or positively on the day of the report, but the key for investors is to stay abreast of the market's prevailing trend. Visit IBD University for a primer on how to time the stock market and read The Big Picture column every day.John Williams, president of the San Francisco Federal Reserve, laid out that case in August: "The current pace of job gains is well above what we need, which I put to be somewhere around 80,000 a month, although estimates range from 50,000 to around 100,000."Williams added: "We should expect the pace of job gains to slow, and no one should be alarmed when it does."With two more jobs reports after this one before the Fed meets Dec. 13 and 14, North figures it would take three weak reports to derail a year-end hike.RELATED:Divided Fed Holds Off On Rate Hike, Sees Slower Tightening PathThe August Jobs Report Was The Weakest Since 2010

Oil climbed above $50 a barrel in New York for the first time since June as declines in U.S. crude inventories and OPEC's pledge to reduce supply lifted hopes the global glut may clear.Futures increased 1.2%. U.S. crude stockpiles shrank below 500 million barrels last week for the first time since January, government data show. OPEC pledged in Algiers on Sept. 28 to reduce the group's output to 32.5 million to 33 million barrels a day in a bid to shrink the world's bloated oil supplies and boost prices.The market is set to remain oversupplied in 2017 and prices will stall at $55 a barrel as shale drillers get back to work, Goldman Sachs Group Inc.'s Head of Commodities Research Jeff Currie said."The main issue is the big decline in North American storage," said Tim Pickering, founder and chief investment officer of Auspice Capital Advisors Ltd. in Calgary. "The OPEC agreement is just spin to help support the market."Oil has advanced 13% since the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to the first production cut in eight years. Some analysts have expressed doubt that individual output quotas — to be determined at a meeting of the group in Vienna on Nov. 30 — will be sufficient to erode the market surplus as several countries boost production to restore disrupted supplies.West Texas Intermediate for November delivery rose 61 cents to $50.44 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. It's the highest close since June 9. Total volume traded was 14% above the 100-day average at 2:48 p.m.Open interest in WTI, or the number of contracts outstanding, rose to 1.91 million as of Wednesday, the most in three years, according to CME Group Inc. data compiled by Bloomberg.Brent for December settlement rose 65 cents, or 1.3%, to $52.51 a barrel on the London-based ICE Futures Europe exchange. It's the highest close since June 8. The global benchmark crude ended the session at a $1.53 premium to WTI for December delivery.U.S. crude stockpiles dropped by 2.98 million barrels for a fifth weekly decline, the Energy Information Administration reported Wednesday. A Bloomberg survey had forecast a supply gain. Crude production declined for a second week to 8.5 million barrels a day."Crude inventories dropped by more than 25 million barrels in September," said Bill O'Grady, chief market strategist at Confluence Investment Management in St. Louis, which oversees $5.2 billion. "You should see prices rally after such a big number."OPEC members will meet next week for talks on implementing an output-cut deal, with Russia joining to discuss how producers from outside the group can participate in the plan, Venezuelan Oil Minister  Eulogio Del Pino said in a government statement late Wednesday. Ministers from Saudi Arabia, Algeria, Gabon, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates will attend a meeting in Istanbul, along with Alexander Novak from non-OPEC member Russia, he said."The drop in crude inventories over the last several weeks is seen by some as a sign that the market's rebalancing," said John Kilduff, a partner at Again Capital LLC, a New York hedge fund focused on energy. "It has a lot to do with an increase in crude-oil exports. The local glut is easing but that's not helping the global glut."Hurricane Matthew is heading for Southeast U.S. and may disrupt East Coast fuel shipments. Matthew's top winds have grown to 140 miles (220 kilometers) per hour, up from 125 mph just hours ago as it churns in the Atlantic 125 miles east-southeast of West Palm Beach, according to the National Hurricane Center.Diesel futures for November delivery climbed 0.9 percent to $1.5958 a gallon, the highest close since Oct. 8, 2015. November gasoline advanced 0.3% to $1.4978 a gallon.The crude rally is threatened by the strengthening dollar, O'Grady said. The U.S. currency climbed against most of its peers as better-than-forecast jobless claims data boosted speculation that the Federal Reserve will increase interest rates this year. A stronger greenback reduces the appeal of commodities as an investment. Precious and industrial metals declined Thursday.

Brexit is back in the news, but this time it's weighing on gold prices and gold mining stocks. The difference: Unlike in June, there's no real panic, just a vague sense of foreboding, but nothing bad enough to keep the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates.December gold closed down 3.3% to $1,269.70 an ounce on Tuesday, the biggest one-day decline since December 2013. It was the sixth straight losing session as gold undercut a key technical level.Gold price moves have a big impact on the profitability of gold miners, which tumbled on the stock market today. Royal Gold (RGLD) fell more than 9% to close at 68.64 Tuesday, hitting its lowest level since June 29. Newmont Mining (NEM) shares plunged 10.1% to 34.25, the lowest since June 22 — the day before the U.K. voted to leave the European Union.SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), one of the most popular gold ETFs, fell 3.5% to 120.97, its lowest level since June 23.A stronger dollar and tighter Fed also can be a negative for emerging markets and industrial metals. Shares of diversified miners BHP Billiton (BHP) and Rio Tinto (RIO) fell modestly. BHP fell 0.6% to 34.65, still extended from a recent buy range. Rio Tinto sank 1.4% to 33.10 after briefly rising above a 33.87 buy point.IBD'S TAKE: The industrial metals sector finally hit bottom early this year after years of falling commodity prices due to overcapacity and the slowdown in China. Here's how the mining industry has been restructuring. Keep an eye on Rio Tinto, which is near a buy point. For a primer on timing stock purchases, visit IBD University.The sense of panic after the U.K. Brexit vote initially sent gold prices surging 8% to a two-year high of $1,366 on July 6. That panic quickly dissipated as Britain's economy showed little immediate evidence of trouble.But British Prime Minister Theresa May has committed to officially launch the two-year process for exiting the EU by the end of March and has reportedly signaled a "hard Brexit." Now markets are beginning to brace for somewhat negative economic news coming out of Europe.Incremental economic weakness in Europe is bound to keep the Bank of England, European Central Bank and Bank of Japan on a course of easier policy even as the Fed gets set to tighten, albeit at a snail's pace.That central bank divergence is a recipe for a stronger dollar. The U.S. dollar index, which tracks the greenback against a basket of developed market currencies rose 0.5% on Tuesday to 96.14, hitting its highest level since early August. Meanwhile, the British pound fell to $1.27, its lowest level since 1985, down from $1.48 before the Brexit vote.On Tuesday, markets were still pricing in 63% odds of a quarter-point rate hike at the Fed's Dec. 14 meeting, according to CME Group's FedWatch tool.A stronger dollar tends to make gold less essential as a store of value — at least in the absence of a global panic. Despite the higher dollar, which is a negative for the dollar-based earnings of U.S. multinationals, major stock indexes were mixed in early afternoon trade on Tuesday, meaning that most investors are taking the latest Brexit news in stride for now.RELATED:Do Gold And Silver Have Anything Left In The Tank?Easy Fed Policy Gives Boost To Gold Stocks, Mining GiantsSmall Caps And Tech Funds Set Records As Investors Cheer A Dovish Fed

Federal Reserve policymakers and financial markets are on the same page when it comes to the next three meetings. The real question is what happens after that, and the Fed on Wednesday is unlikely to be able to assuage concerns about the pace of future rate hikes following recent data pointing to slowing growth and rising inflation.If that combination were to persist, which is no sure thing, a diet of gradual Fed rate hikes could be unappetizing to markets and perhaps harder for the economy to digest. Yet the rise in the 10-year Treasury yield in recent weeks, even amid a string of disappointing data, suggests investors are increasingly on guard for this scenario.Still, with no action expected from the Fed on Wednesday, the Bank of Japan's policy decision hours before the U.S. central bank issues its statement may grab investors' attention. Japan's central bank is expected to take more aggressive action to revive growth and inflation after its surprise move to adopt negative interest rates in early 2016 fell flat.Chances for a Fed interest-rate hike on Wednesday are between slim and none. Likewise, economists see virtually no chance at all for a hike on Nov. 2, days before the presidential election. Though Fed policymakers would never say so, they may be as concerned about the economic reaction to a Donald Trump victory as they were about a U.K. vote to leave the European Union, though those latter concerns seem to have been overwrought at this snapshot in time.As for December, markets are pricing in a 55% chance of a rate hike. After that, markets see only about a 25% chance of an additional rate hike before September 2017, the CME Group FedWatch tool shows.Yet, even as data-dependent Fed policymakers acknowledge a high degree of uncertainty about the outlook for growth and inflation, the tilt of their comments over the past month has pointed toward a path of rate hikes that is somewhat less gradual than markets anticipate.IBD'S TAKE: Hawkish Fed policymakers have been able to point to tightening labor markets. But the mostly timely job health gauge just took a wrong turn.Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen said in her Aug. 26 speech in Jackson Hole, Wyo., that the U.S. economy is "now nearing the Federal Reserve's statutory goals of maximum employment and price stability," setting the stage for a near-term rate hike.In a Sept. 9 speech, the generally dovish Eric Rosengren, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, signaled concern about the economy overheating: "A failure to continue on the path of gradual removal of accommodation could shorten, rather than lengthen, the duration of this recovery."Incoming economic data have been on the weak side, with August retail sales falling and a 151,000 job gain obscuring a big drop in the workweek, but it's not clear that the Fed will adjust its language accordingly. Meanwhile, core consumer price inflation continued to accelerate, rising 2.3% from a year ago.So-called "bond king" Jeffrey Gundlach, CEO of DoubleLine Capital, predicted in a Reuters interview on Sept. 9 that interest rates had bottomed and suggested that the Fed, talking about hiking as growth slowed, risked taking a "bond unfriendly turn."There are two things that might save the day for markets though on Wednesday. One is that the Fed statement, or Yellen in her press conference, could stress that the Fed is willing to let inflation overshoot its 2% target for an extended period. The other is that Japan may unload significant new firepower which convinces markets that, despite the Fed's itchy trigger finger, the era of easy central banks is still in force.

Dividend stocks are always in vogue with income investors, but their appeal tends to widen when the market's direction is unclear -- as it is right now. Hallmarks of a solid income play include a steady earnings track record and a stable yield. If a company also regularly increases its dividend payout, that's a plus. Without further ado, here are…

Stocks turned higher after a weak open as investors began to absorb the growing possibility that the U.S. central bank is seriously considering raising the cost of money for the first time since December.The Nasdaq composite led with a gain of 0.9% after opening mildly lower. The S&P 500 climbed 0.6% and the Dow Jones industrials 0.4%.In the Nasdaq, quartz kitchen countertops firm Caesarstone (CSTE) was one of the biggest gainers, up 14% in fast turnover. The stock is still waist-deep in basing mode after a severe slide in August 2015 that came ahead of a drop in earnings for three quarters in a row.In the Dow 30, telecom-related stocks paced the upside. Apple (AAPL) rose nearly 2% to 104.81, rebounding back above the critical 50-day line, while Verizon (VZ) rallied 0.5%. Verizon is reclaiming a portion of Friday's 3.3% slide and trying to hold above its 200-day moving average.A recent pullback since early July has sent Verizon back into the belly of a prior cup base that formed between April 5 and June 22, featuring a 54.59 buy point. Verizon broke out in late June in heavy volume but rallied just 4% before retreating. Wall Street sees Q3 earnings slipping 4% to $1 a share, which would mark a second straight quarter of shrinking profit.A few retailing leaders are trying to recoup some of Friday's sharp losses. Ollie's Bargain Outlet (OLLI) is attempting to stem a five-day slide, rebounding 1%. Five Below (FIVE) is up 1%. The seller of items $5 and under took out its 50-day moving average in heavy turnover on Aug. 16.Transport-related firms continued to pull back as the Dow Jones transports fell nearly 0.6%, but the sector index fought its way back to rise nearly 0.3%.American Airlines (AAL) fell 2% but is off session lows after undercutting its 200-day moving average early. The stock has been rebounding since late June and is trying to form a new cup base. American Air reported a 2.8% drop in revenue passenger miles in August vs. a year ago as capacity edged up 1.4%. The total passenger load factor, a measure of the degree of airplane seats filled, slipped to 82.9% from 86.5%.AA also expects total revenue per available seat mile to fall 3%-5% in the third quarter vs. a year ago.The market will likely keep a sharp eye on comments from Federal Reserve officials Neel Kashkari and Lael Brainard, who are both scheduled to speak at 1 p.m. ET. Kashkari heads the Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank and Brainard is a member of the Fed's board of governors. The Fed is slated to meet on interest rate policy on Sept. 20-21. According to the CME Group, the fed funds interest rate futures market now shows a minute probability that short-term interest rates will be raised 25 basis points to a target range of 0.5%-0.75%.IBD'S TAKE: The stock market is showing again that it's under heavy selling pressure, and the current outlook was switched to "Uptrend under pressure" on Friday. The best time to buy stocks is when the outlook shows a market in a confirmed uptrend. Read The Big Picture column every day to stay on top of these key junctures in the market so you can maximize your returns and minimize losses.

The U.S. economy added 151,000 jobs in August, the Labor Department said, 24,000 less than expected. The jobless rate held steady at 4.9%.The report was viewed as close to Goldilocks — not too hot, not too cold — because it's likely to keep the Federal Reserve on hold when it meets on Sept. 21.Major stock indexes saw moderate gains after the report. The 10-year Treasury yield dipped slightly after the lower-than-expected job gain, but subsequently turned higher. As of midmorning, markets were pricing in about a 25% chance of an interest-rate hike in September, unchanged from the prior day. The probability of a December hike -- now about 57%, according to the CME Group FedWatch tool -- actually rose slightly.There were some definite soft spots in the report. Hourly wage gains slowed to a 2.4% annual gain from July's cycle-high of 2.7%. The average workweek ticked down to 34.3 hours from 34.4. That combination, along with slower job growth, means slower overall income growth may weigh on consumption.IBD'S TAKE: The Federal Reserve is likely to resume hiking interest rates later this year. How will markets react? Will improved earnings outweigh higher interest rates? Understanding the stock market's prevailing trend is a key consideration in when to buy stocks or take defensive positions. For a primer, visit IBD University.The goods-producing sector of the economy shed 24,000 jobs, with losses of 14,000 in manufacturing, 6,000 in construction and 4,000 in mining. Temp workers assigned through employment agencies fell 11,900.Job gains came in leisure and hospitality (29,000), local government (24,000), social services (21,700), professional and technical services (20,100), finance (15,000), retail (15,100), and health care (14,400).June and July employment gains were revised down by a net 1,000. Over the past three months, job gains have averaged 232,000, but that likely overstates the strength of the labor market because it includes a rebound from May's inexplicably weak gain.RELATED:The August Jobs Report Was The Weakest Since 2010

U.S stocks rumbled ahead Friday morning as the bulls took cheer from a weak jobs report.The Nasdaq rose 0.5%, while the S&P 500 and the blue chip Dow Jones industrial average matched the gain. Volume in the stock market today was running higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq.The market was back to its bad news is good news for the interest-rate outlook. With the unexpectedly weak payroll numbers for August (151,000 jobs added vs. 175,000 expected), the focus shifts back to the Federal Reserve. The Fed had been hinting at a rate hike, but Friday's number might either make that less likely or at least push back the timetable.CME Group's FedWatch Tool pegged the odds of a rate hike in September at 21%, down from the previous session's 24%. The Federal Reserve's next meeting will be conducted Sept. 20-21.Meanwhile, the jobless rate held steady at 4.9%. While that number might not sound so bad, it disguises sharp differences. For black Americans, the economy probably feels more like an outright recession. The unemployment rate for black Americans is 8.1%. For Americans with a college degree, the rate is 2.7%.Big name stocks were doing well in Friday's early trade.Apple (AAPL) gapped up 1%, retaking its short term, 10-day line. Apple has been brushing up its chart appearance. The stock retook its 50-day and 200-day line in late July. Apple is about 13% off its November high. Apple's stock is sketching a handle, which at this point is high enough to be valid. A potential buy point looms at 110.33.On Wednesday, Apple will hold its traditional event to spotlight its next generation of new products. New versions of the iPhone and Apple Watch are expected.Amazon.com (AMZN) has been doing well recently but in a different way than Apple. Amazon hasn't needed to do the repair work on the chart that Apple has been doing. Amazon has shown disciplined action since breaking out in April. Early Friday, the stock added 0.5%.Factory orders for July were released this morning about a half hour after the market's open. The Street expected 2%, but the percentage came in at 1.9%. Factory orders include durable and non-durable goods and thus are considered more complete than the durable goods report. The durable goods report was released Aug. 25 and delivered a beat -- a 4.4% gain vs. the Street's consensus view of 3.7%.West Texas intermediate crude oil rose almost 3% to just under $45 a barrel.

Major index-tracking ETFs shuffled lower Wednesday as investors digested private-sector jobs data and looked ahead to Friday's official nonfarm payrolls data.The jobs number could have an important bearing on the Federal Reserve's decision on a rate hike. The market currently puts the odds of a rate hike in September at 27%, according to the CME Group's FedWatch tool.The financial sector rose in choppy trade Wednesday, boosted by the prospect of higher rates on the horizon.SPDR S&P Bank (KBE) inched up 0.1% on the stock market today.So did Financial Select Sector SPDR (XLF), an exchange traded fund that holds banks, insurers and diversified financial services companies. XLF has advanced for five straight sessions and on Wednesday struck a fresh 2016 high.Banks benefit from higher rates, which boost their net interest margins, or the spread between their borrowing costs and lending rates.Investors have been piling into financial-sector equity funds, according to analytics firm XTF. Vanguard Financials (VFH) absorbed roughly $502 million in the week ended Aug. 30 -- more than any of its sector equity peers and second overall after SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), which attracted $1.9 billion. IShares U.S. Financials (IYF) raked in $233 million over the same period.Energy led declining sectors in the S&P 500, down 1.6%. A stronger dollar has been weighing on crude prices.IBD'S TAKE: The path of rate hikes is the big issue for investors, but mixed messages from Fed officials underscore just how unsure policymakers are about the future.Gold fell further Wednesday ahead of Friday's jobs report. An uptick in expectations that the Fed could raise interest rates sooner rather than later has lately boosted the dollar, while dealing a blow to the precious-metal and mining companies.SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) closed below the keenly watched $125 support level Wednesday. The ETF tracks the price of gold and sits 4% below its early-July high of 131.15.VanEck Vectors Gold Miners (GDX) lost 1.6%.Here's how major exchange traded funds across major asset classes performed today, with IBD Relative Strength Ratings.The RS Rating is a measure of a stock's price performance over the last 12 months, compared with all stocks and ETFs, on a scale of 1 to a best-possible 99.Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing:SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), -0.3%, RS 54PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), -0.1%, RS 58SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), -0.3%, RS 54IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), -0.4%, RS 62IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), -0.6%, RS 65IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), -0.2%, RS 33Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), -1.0%, RS 73SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), -0.2%, RS 71United States Oil (USO), -3.4%, RS 16IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), 0%, RS 39PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), 0%, RS 27IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures (VXX), +0.4%, RS 1Related:Bank Funds Lead MarketGold ETFs, Stocks Risk MeltdownIs Gold Rally Over?

Stocks reversed lower in afternoon trading Friday after Fed chief Janet Yellen said the economy was strong enough to justify a rate hike and her No. 2 said that could mean a move in September.Yellen said a strong labor market had strengthened the case for a rate increase. She said the Fed forecasts moderate growth in GDP and inflation rising to 2% over the next few years. Fed Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer said her remarks were consistent with a September rate increase. He saw the possibility of two rate hikes this year.Stocks, which had extended modest gains on Yellen's comments, reversed lower. The major averages are off session lows, with the Nasdaq down 0.1%, the S&P 500 off 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average retreating 0.3%. Volume was tracking higher than the same time Thursday on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq exchanges in the stock market today.Yellen's much-anticipated speech at Jackson Hole, Wyo., led Fed funds futures traders to up their bets for a rate increase, but only after the election. But they now see a 30% chance of a rate hike at the Sept. 21 meeting and a 36% chance at the Nov. 2 meeting -- both up modestly after Fischer's comments. But they see 58% change of a rate increase at the Dec. 14 meeting, according to the CME Group's FedWatch Tool. They still haven't priced in a second hike as likely at any point through next July.Bank stocks turned mixed. Bank of America (BAC) rose 1.4% and Citigroup (C) 0.6%. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) briefly turned negative but are now up 0.2%.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) disappointed investors even though it beat estimates on the top and bottom lines. Q3 guidance came up a little short. Shares slumped nearly 6%. The stock has undercut its 50-day moving average.Nautilus (NLS) muscled higher for a 6% gain, emerging from a wide and loose consolidation on big volume. It will replace Outerwall (OUTR) in the small-cap S&P 600 index after the close Sept. 1. Outerwall is being bought out by Apollo Global Management.

Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen said Friday that the case for a rate hike has "strengthened" in recent months, as labor market slack is fading.The U.S. economy is "now nearing the Federal Reserve's statutory goals of maximum employment and price stability," Yellen said.Financial markets, which already have been pricing in a good chance of a rate hike in December, initially took her comments in stride. Investors are less concerned about the timing of the next hike than the one after that. Treasury yields initially rose a bit, then headed slightly lower after release of Yellen's speech transcript.That was before Fed Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer told CNBC that he saw Yellen's comments as consistent with a rate hike at the September meeting. Further, he said, a second increase could come as early as December, adding that the Fed won't know what's appropriate "until we see the data."Those comments caused a bit more turbulence, with the 10-year Treasury yield bouncing from an intraday low of 1.53% to 1.59%. Major stock indexes gave up modest gains stock market today and turned red, though afternoon losses were slim.After Fischer's comments market pricing still points to the next hike being in December, CME Group's FedWatch tool shows, though the odds of a hike in September edged up from 21% to 30%.But if Fischer's comments about two hikes this year begin to look realistic, bond market pricing will have to shift pretty markedly. Right now, markets are pricing in just a 31% chance of a second hike coming by the meeting on July 26, 2017.Yellen's speech and Fischer's comments both underscore just how unsure Fed policymakers are about the future. In addition to talking about economic data showing the Fed's goals of full employment and 2% inflation may be around the corner, Yellen highlighted arguments pointing to very low interest rates for a long time to come."By some calculations, the real neutral rate is currently close to zero, and it could remain at this low level if we were to continue to see slow productivity growth and high global saving," Yellen said.The neutral interest rate is the rate at which monetary policy is neither accommodative nor restrictive.The path of rate hikes next year is the big issue for investors. Even as markets have shifted in recent weeks toward expecting a rate hike as early as December, the 10-year Treasury yield has drifted slightly lower. The reason markets have been so calm about the next rate increase is that investors don't expect an ensuing hike until at least the fall of 2017.Yellen, as expected, didn't offer any precise timing for the next Fed interest rate hike. Markets had already moved up the expected timing after a run of mostly better-than-expected data, including the strong July jobs report, a jump in new-home sales and a surge in durable goods orders. New data on Friday were on the soft side, though, with second-quarter GDP growth revised down to 1.1%, and the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index slipping unexpectedly.Banks, which stand to benefit from higher rates, perked up with Yellen's comments about a stronger case for a rate hike, but later gave up much of their gains. JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) each saw minor gains, but Bank of America (BAC) was up 1.4%.

After the 2013 "Taper Tantrum," the pre-hike panic in 2015 and the dot-plot disturbance at the start of 2016, markets have exhibited an eerie sense of calm in recent weeks over the prospect of the Federal Reserve tightening policy.The surprise is that even as the strong 255,000 job gain reported on Aug. 5 increased expectations for a rate hike before year end — markets are now pricing in a roughly 50% chance — the 10-year Treasury yield has drifted lower and remains not too far above the record lows set in the days after the U.K.'s Brexit vote.Into this placid environment, Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen is set to tread on Friday as she delivers a speech at 10 a.m. ET at the biggest central banking conference of the year. The title of this year's Jackson Hole, Wyo., confab is "Designing Resilient Monetary Policy Frameworks for the Future" or, in simpler terms, how can the Fed save our slow-growth economy when the next recession hits.Fed watchers don't expect Yellen to offer any clarity on when the next rate hike will be, but investors will be listening closely for any hints about where rate policy may go in 2017 — and which camp she sides with. Right now there's a pretty stark divide within the central bank: Some policymakers see little reason to be proactive in hiking rates when growth is slow and inflation is low; others think economy is at full employment, inflation is rising toward the 2% target and it's time to implement a diet of gradual rate hikes.Here's what's behind the bond market's Jedi-like calm: Investors don't seem phased by the growing prospect of a rate hike in coming months because they're convinced that the rate hikes after that one will be a long time in coming. That's a markedly different attitude than prior occasions when the Federal Reserve shifted policy. The tapering of quantitative easing purchases in 2013 and the telegraphing of rate hikes to come in mid-2015 both precipitated a big rise in market interest rates. Then the Fed's dot-plot chart last December, which signaled four rate hikes in 2016, helped send markets into a tailspin at the start of the year.At the moment, the CME Group's Fed Watch tool sees just a single hike through next July, with just a 23% chance of a second hike at the meeting on July 26, 2017.The outlook for a very slow pace of rate hikes follows "rather sobering" economic news, says Sara Johnson, senior research director of global economics at IHS Global Insight."Sluggish growth in the second quarter, three quarters of decline in capital spending" and continued slow productivity growth have led policymakers to repeatedly curb their expectations for the economy, Johnson said.Still, she said, even if markets appear calm about the next rate hike, there's no telling if they'll remain so once a rate hike becomes a reality. She notes that emerging markets have rallied in recent months as investors have become willing to take on more risk, but that risk-aversion tends to creep in when the Fed is tightening.Bond yields remained little changed Thursday, while the major stock indexes fell slightly.

U.S. stock indexes clung to small losses Friday afternoon on a day expected to show higher volume due to options expirations.The Nasdaq sanded off 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average shaved 0.3% each. Volume in the stock market today was running higher on both major exchanges.The Dow Jones utility average dropped 1.6% on further signs that the Federal Reserve may be preparing to raise interest rates. CME Group's Fed Watch Tool sees an 18% chance of a rate hike in September, but a 43% chance of one in December. Higher rates could make the dividends of utilities look less attractive.Most utilities have recently lost their 50-day moving average line. Southern Company (SO), for example, shows typical action -- losing the line Aug. 11 and since unable to reclaim it.One stock that is comfortably above its 50-day line and that shows no signs of weakness is retailer Ulta Beauty (ULTA). The stock rose 0.6% and notched another new high. Ulta Beauty is slated to report quarterly results after the close Thursday. Wall Street expects earnings to advance 21% to $1.39 a share. That would be the slowest quarterly growth in nine quarters. However, Ulta beat views last time around by 12%.Among the blue chips, losers led winners by a 9-4 ratio in the Dow. The biggest percentage losers were Wal-Mart Stores (WMT), down 1.5%, and McDonald's (MCD), down 1.3%. The best performer was Nike (NKE), up 3%.Of the 197 industry groups followed by IBD, farm machinery was the day's No. 1 winner, up about 5%. The worst performer was the metal products distributor group, down 6%, but that was chiefly because of one stock: Olympic Steel (ZEUS) plunged 16%. Analysts at KeyBanc Capital Markets downgraded the stock from sector weight to underweight. KeyBanc also downgraded other steel-related stocks, saying they expect a weak supply-demand balance.

Stocks were lower heading into midday Friday on renewed speculation that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates, but the major averages pared lossesSan Francisco Fed President John Williams said Thursday said rates should rise "sooner rather than later." Williams, a nonvoting member of the FOMC, has close ties to Janet Yellen, his predecessor at the San Francisco Fed.New York Fed President William Dudley had already said two solid jobs reports have "helped allay concerns that arose earlier this year that jobs growth was beginning to stall." Yellen is scheduled to speak next Friday.The Nasdaq fell initially, but was up 0.1% in recent action. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average each pared losses to 0.2% on the stock market today. Volume was tracking higher on both exchanges, fueled by options expiration.Still, traders in fed funds futures are pricing in only an 18% chance of a rate hike at the Fed's Sept. 21 meeting. The odds rise to 25% for the Nov. 2 meeting, but are at 53% for the Dec. 14 meeting, according to the CME Group FedWatch Tool. Until recently, investors weren't expecting a hike until well into 2017.The dollar traded 0.4% higher compared to a basket of 16 currencies. The 10-year Treasury note rose nearly 5 basis points to 1.58%.GrubHub (GRUB) rose nearly 5% in above-average volume. On Wednesday, it announced it was launching its Seamless turnkey delivery service in Manhattan. The stock vaulted 24% July 28 as investors cheered a better-than-expected earnings report.IBD'S TAKE: See how GrubHub stacks up against other stocks in the internet content industry group with IBD's Stock Checkup.Foot Locker (FL) gapped up and sprinted to a gain of nearly 11%. It reported EPS of 94 cents vs. estimates of 90 cents. Revenue was $1.78 billion against estimates of $1.76 billion. Second-quarter same-store sales rose 4.7%.

Gold and silver stocks such as Barrick Gold (ABX) and Silver Wheaton (SLW) sank Friday, as Federal Reserve officials continued to talk up the chance of an interest rate hike, lifting the dollar.Gold futures fell 0.9% Friday while silver slid 2.25%.Gold stocks have enjoyed a monthslong run-up amid worldwide economic uncertainty. But Fed officials this week have offered a more bullish outlook."In the context of a strong domestic economy with good momentum, it makes sense to get back to a pace of gradual rate increases, preferably sooner rather than later," San Francisco Fed President John Williams said on Thursday.Williams is seen as a close ally of Chairwoman Janet Yellen, who will speak next week.New York Fed President William Dudley this week also told Fox Business that a September rate hike was "possible." Atlanta Fed President Dennis Lockhart this week said that he was "not prepared to rule out at least one rate hike before year's end."The CME Fed Watch Tool now sees a 53% chance of a rate hike at the December meeting. Previously, markets had predicted no move until 2017.Those remarks followed a more cautious sentiment indicated from the Fed's July meeting minutes, released Wednesday.The gold-backed SPDR Gold Trust (GLD) ETF slipped 0.9% in the stock market today, grinding its way through a flat base begun last month. Royal Gold (RGLD), which owns and manages royalty interests in gold mines, lost 1.3%.Silver Wheaton, a "silver streaming" company that makes upfront payments to miners to buy their output in attempt to hedge against the industry's risks, tumbled 4.35%. Silver Wheaton remains well above its 50-day line.IBD'S TAKE: The Mining-Gold/Silver/Gems group is rated No. 1 out of IBD's 197 industries. Look for the top-rated stocks in the group and for those that are consolidating and working toward new buy points. To get started, find the best gold and silver miners at IBD Stock Checkup.Gold and copper producer Barrick Gold, fell 2%, crossing back below its 50-day line after retaking it Thursday. The stock bounced off that key measure of support in May and then July and is fighting to hold the line this week.Gold miner Newmont Mining (NEM) edged down 0.6%. Newmont Mining has not touched its 50-day line since January.RELATED:

Federal Reserve Chairwoman Janet Yellen on Monday highlighted "disappointing" jobs data and subtly shifted her view on when additional rate hikes would be appropriate from "probably in the coming months" to "probably."Yellen omitted any reference to the possible timing of future rate increases, saying that the Fed will have to wrestle with "new questions about the economic outlook" after the May jobs report showing that the economy added just 38,000 jobs last month."Is the markedly reduced pace of hiring in April and May a harbinger of a persistent slowdown in the broader economy?" Yellen asked rhetorically at a speech in Philadelphia.After initially paring gains, stocks rallied to session highs following Yellen's comments, with the S&P 500 hitting a 7-month high intraday and the Nasdaq reaching the highest since late December. Yet investors may not put too much faith in Yellen's ability to pull her colleagues in a more dovish direction. After an ultra-dovish speech in late March, markets were betting that the Fed wouldn't hike until December or even until 2017.Other Fed members began warning earlier in May that markets were wrong. Then, on May 27 at Harvard University, Yellen also signaled that a summer rate hike was in the cards: "Probably in the coming months (a rate) move would be appropriate."Other Fed policymakers chimed in on Monday, essentially saying that the May jobs report was a bump in the road that pretty much eliminates chances for a hike in June but not necessarily July.Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren, speaking in Finland, said that the 4.7% jobless rate is his estimate for "full employment" and that he expects growth to remain sufficient "to justify a gradual removal" of monetary policy accommodation.Atlanta Fed President Dennis Lockhart said that while the Fed shouldn't hike in June, he still sees the economy on a moderate growth path and thinks two hikes before year's end will be appropriate.Yellen said she is cautiously optimistic about the economy: "I continue to think that the federal funds rate will probably need to rise gradually over time to ensure price stability and maximum sustainable employment in the longer run."Yet she noted a number of concerns beyond the lousy jobs report, including weak business investment, slow productivity growth, international uncertainties from the U.K. possibly leaving the European Union, and slowing growth in China.Further, Yellen said she sees current policy as only "modestly accommodative" and said that it may be appropriate to let the unemployment rate undershoot the Fed's objective by a bit to help lift inflation toward its 2% target more quickly.While Yellen might not have a lot of support on the Fed for that approach, it's clear that after a surprisingly weak May jobs report, policymakers are more data-dependent than ever.The CME FedWatch Tool now sees only a 4% chance of a June rate hike and about a 26% chance of a July move. Even a tightening by September is now just below 50-50. Before the jobs report, the odds were about 25% to 30% for June hike and roughly 60% by July.

A surprisingly weak employment report shook stock market investors Friday morning, but stocks finished off their worst levels of the day.The Nasdaq led the way down with a 0.6% loss in the stock market today. The S&P 500 dipped 0.3%, and the Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.2%.The Labor Department reported the economy created 38,000 jobs in May, well below the 158,000 forecast. After the open, the ISM services index came in at 52.9 for May, while April factory orders climbed 1.9%. Both were short of economists' forecasts.The economic news rattled other markets as well. The dollar dropped sharply, gold rose, and Treasuries soared as yields fell. The benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures contract for July delivery dropped 48 cents, or 1%, to $48.69 a barrel.Fed funds futures traders threw in the towel on any chance the Fed will hike rates at its June 15 meeting. The odds now stand at 3.8%, down from 28% a week ago. For a hike at the July 27 meeting, the odds are 32.4%, down from 48% last week, according to the CME Group FedWatch tool.Among the day's bright spots was chipmaker Broadcom (AVGO), which gapped out of a base to close 5% higher on big volume. Late Thursday, the company reported better-than-expected earnings.Find Out More About Broadcom's Fundamentals. Is It The Best Of The Chipmakers?Gold miners were the leading industry group, soaring 9%; coal stocks rose 3.4%, and metals miners gained 2.9%. Defensive names in the utilities industry also rose.Big banks were among the worst performers, off 2.3%.No major economic indicators are scheduled for release Monday.

Stocks were off earlier lows but still underwater in early afternoon trading Friday, as Goldman Sachs (GS), JPMorgan (JPM) and other names took a beating amid a bad jobs report.The Nasdaq was down 0.7%, the S&P 500 shed 0.5%, and the Dow industrials gave up 0.3%. Volume was tracking higher across the board vs. the same time Thursday.Nonfarm payrolls rose 38,000 in May, well below economists' expectations for 158,000 added jobs. In other economic news, the ISM services index came in below forecasts at 52.9 for May, while April factory orders climbed 1.9%, also short of views. The odds of a Federal Reserve rate hike in June fell to 4%, according to CME Group's FedWatch tool.The disappointing data underscored concerns about slowing economic growth, sending investors flocking to defensive stocks. Gold miners and utilities were among the biggest gainers, with gold jumping 2.5% to $1.242.30 an ounce. The 10-year Treasury yield fell eight basis points to 1.71%.Banks and other financial stocks were among the biggest losers in the stock market today, as Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan gave up more than 2% each on the Dow.But some stocks bucked the decline. Broadcom (AVGO) gapped up, soaring 5% to a new high in heavy volume and surpassing a 159.75 flat-base buy point. It's still in buy range from the entry. After the close Thursday, the chip designer reported fiscal Q2 earnings and revenue that topped views. Several analysts boosted their price targets Friday.Find out how your stock ranks in terms of fundamental and technical ratings at IBD Stock Checkup.On the IBD 50, Five Below (FIVE) added 2% in brisk trade to reach its highest level since December 2014. Shares are on track for their eighth straight advance. RBC Capital raised its price target to 48 from 44. The discount retailer late Thursday reported Q1 EPS that topped forecasts, though its Q2 and full-year sales outlook was light.Also in the discount retail group, fellow IBD 50 stock Dollar General (DG) climbed nearly 1% to a new high. Volume was about 35% lighter than average. The stock is near the top of a buy range from an 87.52 entry.

Stocks collided with the worst payroll report in years Friday, but somehow the indexes came away with only minor dents. The Nasdaq dropped 0.6%, while the S&P 500 trimmed 0.3%. The IBD 50 carved off 0.5%. Volume fell on the Nasdaq but rose on the NYSE. The S&P 500 picked up a distribution day, while the Nasdaq dodged a distribution…

The troubling takeaway from the surprisingly weak May jobs numbers is that the economy is stuck in slow-growth mode for the foreseeable future.While last month's overall gain of 38,000 jobs, including a 25,000 rise in private payrolls, was dragged down temporarily by the labor strike of 35,000 Verizon (VZ) communications workers, the weakness was broad-based. On net, just 51.3% of industries added jobs, the lowest since February 2010, Labor Department data showed.Considering that Verizon likely brought in some temp workers during the now-resolved strike, private payrolls were close to flat in May outside of health care, which added 45,700 jobs last month and just under a half million over the past year.Although there were some pockets of hiring strength, the weak job gains and downward revisions totaling 59,000 to the increases reported in March and April suggest that growth is getting much harder to come by as the economic expansion gets long in the tooth.The slowdown looks like more than a one-month blip: The 155,000 private-sector jobs added over the past two months is the worst stretch since January 2011 -- even assuming that the strike artificially knocked 25,000-35,000 off the total.As markets priced in a slower timetable for Federal Reserve rate hikes, shares of Bank of America (BAC), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) sold off hard on the stock market today.Instead of a likely hike in July, markets now see the Fed waiting until November, the CME Group FedWatch tool showed. The 10-year Treasury yield plunged to 1.71%, and the dollar fell 1.5% against other major currencies.One decent bit of news in the employment report is that the trend of firming wages remained intact, as hourly pay rose 0.2% from April and 2.5% from a year ago. That's consistent with anecdotal reports of companies having to pay more to attract or keep good workers, and many finding qualified workers in short supply.Wal-Mart (WMT), Target (TGT), Costco (COST), Panera Bread (PNRA) and Wendy's (WEN) have all said they've raised pay in recent months.The drop in the unemployment rate to 4.7% from 5% in April appears at first to be consistent with a tight labor market. Still, the sudden drop in joblessness, which reflected fewer people in the workforce rather than an increase in employment, should be taken with a grain of salt, given the household survey's higher margin of error.Yet the overriding problem is that employers, who are now paying new employees more, are seeing profit margins pressured and finding that opportunities for profitable growth have narrowed."The 'disconnect' between weak real GDP growth and strong employment growth seems to be resolving itself as employers are defending profits (and trying to boost productivity) in a soggy environment by managing payroll costs," wrote IHS Global Insight economists Nariman Behravesh and Ozlem Yaylaci.The reality portrayed by the weak jobs report got some confirmation from the Institute for Supply Management's survey of non-manufacturing industries, with the index slipping to a 28-month low of 52.9 in May from 55.7 in April -- well below expectations. The employment gauge fell into negative territory, dropping 3.3 points to 49.7, just below the neutral 50 level.A range of other economic data points and industry trends suggest a similar conclusion that the much-anticipated pick-up in growth may not materialize.Analysts think U.S. auto sales are close to peaking, and those views were supported by lower sales in May for General Motors (GM) and Ford (F), even as Autodata reports that incentives have climbed north of $3,000 per vehicle.Construction spending fell a surprising 1.8% in April, more than reversing March's gain. To top off that bad news, the construction sector shed 15,000 jobs in May after losing 5,000 in April. Anirban Basu, chief economist at Associated Builders and Contractors, said that many private developers are concerned by possible overbuilding in commercial, office and lodging markets and sense that "the current real estate cycle is now in its seventh inning or later."Wal-Mart closed 154 U.S. stores at the start of the year, and Macy's (M) and other department stores are cutting their square footage as Amazon (AMZN) continues to eat into their business. Even Home Depot (HD), in one of the strongest retail sectors, hasn't added any stores in the U.S. in more than a year.Somehow, the retail sector has seemingly defied gravity when it comes to employment, adding 11,400 jobs last month and 323,000 over the past year. The explanation may be that the workweek has shrunk, since aggregate hours of work in the retail industry are down 0.3% over the past three months.Food services and drinking places added 22,200 jobs in May. But the accommodation sector shed 1,500 jobs, after cutting 2,300 the prior month.Manufacturers cut 18,000 jobs in May. While the sector has stabilized, there's little hope for an upturn, with the dollar still strong and global growth still weak.

After a soft open, the stock market recovered a bit in afternoon trading Wednesday, helped by better-than-expected U.S. manufacturing data.The Nasdaq added 0.1%, the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.1%, and the S&P fell less than 0.1%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking slightly higher than Tuesday's levels in the stock market today.In economic news, the Institute for Supply Management’s U.S. manufacturing index rose 0.5 point in May to 51.3, better than forecasts for a dip to 50.3. The new data, plus strong consumer spending numbers released Tuesday, seemed to bolster the case for a Federal Reserve rate hike sooner rather than later, although the odds have fallen to around 23% for a hike next month, down from 30% last week, according to CME Group FedWatch.In merger news, Salesforce.com (CRM) announced plans to buy Demandware (DWRE) for $2.8 billion, strengthening its e-commerce presence. Shares of Salesforce fell 2% early on the news but recovered to sit mostly unchanged. Demandware soared 56%.In the retail space, Burlington Stores (BURL) added 2% to 61.78. It’s at the high end of a buy range from a 59.02 handle buy point, but the stock is also nearing a breakout over its all-time high of 61.94.Leaderboard currently holds two top performers in the retail sector. See who they are here.In the health care space, IBD 50 name Cambrex (CBM) popped above a cup-with-handle buy point of 51.26. Shares rose 5% to 51.48.PayPal (PYPL) outperformed, rising 1.5% to 38.34. Its 50-day moving average, currently around 39, is a potential resistance level to watch.On the downside, back-and-forth action continued in Alibaba (BABA). Shares slumped 3% on news Japan’s Softbank (SFTBY) is selling a good chunk of Alibaba stock. Alibaba cratered 7% May 25 on news of an SEC probe.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil for July delivery pared losses on reports that OPEC is considering a new output ceiling. The front-month contract eased 0.3% to $48.95 a barrel ahead of Thursday's OPEC meeting in Vienna.

Stocks rose Friday, ending at session highs, as investors shrugged off disappointing economic data and comments by Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen suggesting higher interest rates were on the way.The Nasdaq rose 0.7%, the S&P 500 added 0.4%, and the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.3%. Volume fell about 11% on the NYSE and 7% on the Nasdaq compared to Thursday, according to preliminary data. The market is closed Monday for the Memorial Day holiday.Yellen said an interest rate hike is possible “in the coming months” amid improved economic growth. Traders put the probability of a rate hike at the Fed's June 15 meeting at 30% and the chance of an increase at the July meeting at 62%, according to the CME Group's FedWatch Tool.Also Friday, Q1 GDP was revised upward to 0.8% -- less than expected -- and the University of Michigan’s consumer sentiment gauge for May also fell short of Wall Street’s consensus estimate.Retail stocks once again outperformed in the stock market today.Discount retailer Big Lots (BIG) jumped 14% to a new high in heavy volume after announcing that profit for the fiscal first quarter ended in April jumped 34% from a year earlier to 82 cents a share, well above Wall Street estimates. Revenue rose 3% to $1.3 billion, also well above views.The stock rocketed back above a 46.23 buy point in massive volume, just nine days after it triggered a sell signal by sinking 8% below the entry.Big Lots is the latest discount retailer to spike to new highs following a strong earnings reports. Dollar General (DG) and Dollar Tree (DLTR) continued to rise Friday following earnings-inspired breakouts Thursday.FEI (FEIC) led the S&P 500, jumping 14%, after Thermo Fisher Scientific (TMO) said it would buy the maker of electron microscopes for $4.2 billion.Zoes Kitchen (ZOES), Medtronic (MDT), YY (YY) and Workday (WDAY) are among companies due to report quarterly earnings on Tuesday.

Stocks opened modestly higher but trimmed already-slim gains early into Monday's session.Apple (AAPL) was a big winner in the Dow, up 1.8%, on rumors of large iPhone 7 orders. Apple suppliers rose across the board. IBD 50 name Universal Display (OLED) gapped up 8.6%, helped by positive comments from Goldman Sachs. Broadcom (AVGO) was making a go at reclaiming its 50-day moving average, rising 1.4% in fast turnover.The Nasdaq was up 0.3%, the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.1%, and the S&P 500 was flat on the stock market today.Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren told the Financial Times that the conditions for the Fed's second rate hike were "on the verge of being broadly met."Rosengren is widely known as a Fed dove, so the reported comments appeared to carry more weight. Early last week, the odds of a rate hike at the June Fed meeting were in the low single digits, according to CME Group FedWatch. Now, they're at 26%.Other early movers included Ebix (EBIX). Shares of the top-rated enterprise software firm rose 1.3% after the company declared a 3-for-1 stock split.In merger news, Germany’s Bayer (BAYRY) announced a bid of $122 a share, or $62 billion, for agricultural products maker Monsanto (MON). Monsanto shares were up 5%, while Bayer ADRs fell 5.6%.Meanwhile, Tribune Publishing (TPUB) rejected a sweetened offer from Gannett (GCI). Tribune also announced a $70.5 million investment from Nant Capital LLC. Tribune shareholders didn't like the news, as shares plunged 16%.

A battle for the bigger exchange appeared to escalate between the U.S. and the EU on Tuesday after NYSE owner Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) and CME Group (CME) expressed interest in acquiring the London Stock Exchange Group.The bids under consideration would risk sabotaging Germany-based exchange operator Deutsche Boerse's plans to form a "merger of equals" with the London Stock Exchange Group.That deal, if it happened, would create an organization that would oversee a massive swath of the Continent's trading and cap years of wrangling for dominance between Deutsche Boerse and the LSE. It would also come at the end of a trail of failed attempts by many others to take over the London exchange.Intercontinental Exchange said, in a statement responding to media speculation, that it was "considering making an offer for LSEG" but has made no decision on the matter and hasn't approached the London group. ICE has until March 29 to announce its decision.CME, which deals in the huge derivatives market, was also mulling an offer, the Wall Street Journal reported. CME runs four exchanges, including the New York Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.Shares of CME closed up 1.2% in the stock market today. Intercontinental Exchange fell 2.7%.Both ICE and CME stand to lose out if a deal goes through between the two European companies.The Wall Street Journal noted that a merger could give the NYSE and Nasdaq a run for their money, while the Financial Times said that a deal could shunt CME Group to the sidelines in Europe.Image provided by Shutterstock.

CME Group (CME) is reducing trading hours for livestock futures, the latest measure taken by the Chicago-based exchange in response to beef producers who say there is too much volatility and undue influence from high-frequency traders.A working group will be formed with the National Cattlemen’s Beef Association to examine more changes in trading, including setting up so-called circuit breakers to pause the market, CME Group said Wednesday in a statement. The change in hours was “based on customer requests,” said CME, the owner of the world’s largest futures market.CME Chairman Terry Duffy said at a cattle industry conference in January that he would push for changes in livestock markets to curb volatility that beef producers say make it harder to hedge their financial risk effectively. Last month, the National Cattlemen’s Beef Association said that high-frequency trading and wide price swings made futures “more of a liability than a benefit.”“Nothing is more important to us than the integrity of our markets, which help farmers and ranchers to discover prices and transfer risk,” Tim Andriesen, CME Group managing director of agricultural products, said Wednesday in the statement.Effective Feb. 29, futures and options in cattle, hogs and feeder cattle on CME Globex will trade from 8:30 a.m. to 1:05 p.m. Chicago time, Monday through Friday, pending approval from regulators. Options trading by open outcry will be from 8:30 a.m. to 1:02 p.m.On most days currently, electronic trading runs from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m.In December, a measure of volatility in cattle futures soared to the highest since 2004, while prices increasingly reached daily trading limits. That deterred cattle owners from using the derivatives to protect against price swings, the 28,000-member beef association said in a letter to the exchange Jan. 13.CME Group said its data show that traders not using high-frequency techniques have triggered wide price swings. Duffy said the cattle market may be “broken” because transactions have slumped in cash markets, a benchmark for futures.High-frequency trading accounted for 10% of average daily volume in cattle in 2015, CME Group said at the January industry conference.
