XPresident Trump's directionless policy agenda and his bear hug of dovish Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen are wreaking havoc on market expectations, with an assist from international uncertainty.The 10-year Treasury yield on Thursday sank to 2.23%, a level not seen since the week after Trump's election. Wells Fargo (WFC) tumbled 3.3% to its worst close since Nov. 9, the first day of the postelection rally, after reporting weaker-than-expected revenue. Dow component JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Citigroup (C) cleared analyst estimates with their first-quarter reports, but saw modest early gains turn into losses of about 1%, with both stocks stuck below their 50-day averages.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 index both appeared headed for a third straight lower close as weakness continued to extend beyond financials to infrastructure stocks, another group that soared on the Trump agenda. The Dow, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq composite are all trading below their 50-day moving averages.Dow construction equipment giant Caterpillar (CAT) slipped 1.9%, while steel maker U.S. Steel (X) tumbled 5.9%. U.S. Steel crashed 10% on Wednesday, its worst loss in nearly a year, as steel makers and miners plunged with iron ore prices.IBD'S TAKE: While the stock market rally has stalled out in the U.S., emerging markets stocks are rallying. Learn why they're rising, and which emerging markets are outperforming their peers.This week's action appears to represent the biggest reversal of the Trump effect to date. The reversal is more obvious in the Treasury market, where yields have fallen to their lowest levels in almost five months, than in equity markets that are still not too far from the lofty postelection peaks. Perhaps the clearest evidence of the change is visible in Fed rate expectations.Despite the Fed's stated intention to raise rates twice more this year and also to begin unwinding its balance sheet by a change in its reinvestment policy, which represents a third tightening, markets are now only pricing one more hike this year, according to the CME Group FedWatch tool. What's more, the second rate hike isn't seen until at least March of 2018. That's basically where expectations stood before Trump's election led the Fed to take a hawkish shift.Trump's announcement this week that he is putting repeal of ObamaCare back at the top of his agenda, even though prospects for success look negligible, seem to have cemented doubts that Trump will be able to enact pro-growth tax cuts and infrastructure. That's a bitter pill for investors who had been banking on big corporate tax cuts in the Trump era.The White House also revealed this week that it is undertaking a broad search for options to offset the cost of tax reform. While the possibility of success can't be completely ruled out, the outcome will likely hinge on whether Trump can get near-unanimous support among GOP senators for a big deficit-increasing tax cut at a time of high and rising debt levels.The latest blow to Fed expectations and banks came when Trump told the Wall Street Journal in a Wednesday interview that he liked low interest rates and would consider reappointing Yellen as chair at the end of her term in February 2018. There are three Fed governor openings that Trump has to fill, and there's now substantial doubt that he'll appoint any hawks. That's quite a surprise, considering that Trump said Yellen's low rates had created a "big fat, ugly bubble" during the campaign. Prospects for faster growth and higher rates that allow for a wider margin between lending and borrowing rates had made banks among the big winners of the Trump rally.RELATED:Stock Rally Tiring As Trump Policy Agenda Runs In CirclesThis 'Explosive' Protectionist Signal From Trump Looks Like A Dud

The stock market loves to do the unexpected. Veterans on Wall Street call it a contrarian streak.Did you see the latest example of the market's psychological mischief? On the night of the Nov. 8 presidential election, fear consumed traders. At one point futures on the Dow Jones industrials index plunged 800 points. Yet by Friday, the index finished the week up 959 points, more than 5%.This past week, the popular blue-chip gauge refused to give back any of last week's rally. The Russell 2000, meanwhile, started the week with an upward surge of nearly 1.3%, after catapulting more than 10% higher last week. With less than an hour to go in Friday's trade, the popular small cap index was poised to gain another 2.4%.The S&P 500 closed down less than 1 point on Monday, but also looks to finish higher for the week. That's bullish action, considering that the large-cap benchmark climbed an astonishing 79 points, or 3.8%, last week.The NYSE composite also looks set to gain some additional ground for the week, following a 3.5% gain last week.Apple (AAPL), Alphabet (GOOGL) and Facebook (FB) all struggled on Monday with losses of 2% to 3% each, yet the market cap-weighted Nasdaq composite finished down only 0.4% on Monday. Why? The Nasdaq is certainly dominated by large tech and consumer-oriented companies, but don't forget the thousands of other smaller firms in the fields of banking, retailing, manufacturing, biotechnology and commodities.Did you see solid gains in heavy volume by Airgain (AIRG) (now up 35% past 17.04 IPO base buy point), Cognex (CGNX) (extended 10% past a 53.55 flat base proper entry) and WingStop (WING) (building a new base since Aug. 15)? All of these Nasdaq-listed names rallied big for the week in rapid turnover.Such action is a hint that equity trading desks and large funds aren't finished buying yet, even after last week's big stock market bounce.Looking ahead, will the market do something even more unexpected?To be more specific, will four years of Donald Trump in the White House be just what the doctor ordered to keep the aging stock market rally going even with 7-1/2 years of gains already behind it? And could the rise in U.S. equities even accelerate?America and the world are still pondering the latest sea change in U.S. politics and governing. But the accompanying chart suggests that good times for long-suffering equity investors may be closer around the corner.Why? The market action since 2000 has been showing similar action to an earlier period: 1968 to 1987.For 14 long years from 1968 to 1982, the S&P 500 struggled to break free from a grinding trading range. Slow growth and high inflation kept it trapped in a series of bear markets, the worst of which cut the market in half in 1973-74.That all changed in 1982 when President Ronald Reagan slashed taxes and unleashed an 18-year super bull market.Jump to 2000. After extraordinary stock gains that ultimately ended in extreme excesses, it was time for another long period of consolidation. It took 13 years for the S&P 500 to completely break through to new high ground. But for the past two years, the stock market has been stuck in neutral.History doesn't precisely repeat itself, but as the late writer Mark Twain was once quoted as saying, it does rhyme. Today, if you overlay the current market with the earlier period on the chart, an interesting parallel emerges.

The 10-year Treasury yield added 5 basis points to 2.27%.RELATED:Fed's Yellen: Rate Hike 'Soon,' Will Serve Full TermEconomy Gets A Thumbs Up On Jobs, Homes, Factories And InflationHow Much Would A Six-Month Cut In OPEC Output Actually Help Oil?Are We Approaching The Dawn Of A Secular New Bull Market?

Oil investors traded a record number of bullish options contracts for benchmark U.S. crude, a signal that the market is positioning for a potential OPEC deal to limit production and boost prices.The total volume of calls giving investors the right purchase West Texas intermediate crude rose to the equivalent of 303 million barrels on Tuesday, according to preliminary CME Group data compiled by Bloomberg. That far exceeded a prior record of 221 million, set five and a half years ago. The heaviest trade was concentrated in the first half of next year, with several individual contracts setting all-time highs."There is definitely somebody that thinks that there is a risk of having higher prices in the first half of 2017," Olivier Jakob, managing director of Petromatrix in Zug, Switzerland, said by phone. "It's saying that somebody in the market is either hedging for potential higher prices in 2017, or somebody is taking a bet that prices will be higher next year."Oil prices on Tuesday had the biggest one-day surge since April as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries embarked on a final diplomatic effort to secure an oil-cuts deal. Its top official is heading on a tour of member states while Russia scheduled informal talks in Doha this week with nations including Saudi Arabia. The producer club, meeting formally on Nov. 30 in Vienna, is under pressure to formalize a deal it set out in September that's supposed to limit supply.The surge in calls trading also helped lift the total number of lots traded to an all time high. A total of 434,879 were transacted, the preliminary data show. The prior all-time high was 430,867 contracts, set in May 2011. Each one represents 1,000 barrels. Of the 10 most active contracts on Tuesday, nine were calls.West Texas intermediate for December jumped 5.7% to $45.81 on the Nymex on Tuesday. The advance was the largest since April 8. The grade was down 39 cents at $45.42 at 10:06 a.m. in London.

On the revenue side, Home Depot recorded $23.15 billion. Same-store sales rose 5.5%, which also beat Wall Street's 4.4% estimate. The stock was down 2% after trading higher in the premarket following the earnings beat.Home Depot has been in a downtrend since early August and may be in the process of building the right side of a base. The stock has a great earnings track record and an EPS Rating of 94. However, the RS Rating is a weak 36. Ideally, the RS Rating will improve over the next few weeks if the company's earnings report can prove to be a positive catalyst for the stock.NetEase (NTES) jumped 4% after management authorized up to 1$ billion repurchase of its American depositary receipts. Goldman Sachs (GS) fell 1.5% and JPMorgan (JPM) declined 2%. Facebook (FB), Google (GOOGL) and Amazon (AMZN) all gained at least 2.5%.There was positive economic data out Tuesday morning before the market open. October Retail Sales were 0.8% versus an expected 0.6%. The Empire State Manufacturing Survey came in at 1.5 ahead of the -2.5 estimate. Lastly, US import prices rose 0.5% in October vs. 0.4% estimate, and export prices were up 0.2% vs. 0.1% estimate.The Boston Federal Reserve Bank President Eric Rosengren seemed to reinforce the notion that rising interest rates are imminent in December. "Absent significant negative economic news over the next month, the market's assessment of the likelihood of tightening in December seems plausible," Rosengren said. The forecaster uses 30-Day Fed Fund futures prices to forecast the likelihood of changes in U.S. monetary policy.Other Fed Speakers due up today are Robert Kaplan of the Dallas Federal Reserve and Fed Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer at 1:30 pm ET.Oil surged 4% to $45 a barrel on expectations that an OPEC meeting later this month will result in a production cut. October's 2.8% annual rise in average hourly wages was the best since 2009, but it's a safe bet that the pace of wage gains will keep rising in coming months, likely by a good amount.That may dent the market's confidence that the Federal Reserve, after hiking rates next month, will stay on hold until the very end of 2017.There are three reasons why a further pickup is pretty much baked in the cake:First, labor markets are getting tighter and the competition for good workers is heating up.Starbucks (SBUX) on Oct. 3 gave a wage hike of at least 5% to every barista and manager at all of its U.S. stores. In July, JPMorgan Chase (JPM) CEO Jamie Dimon announced that the company would boost the minimum wage for 18,000 tellers and customer-service workers from $10.15 to $12 over two years.On an Oct. 26 conference call, Panera Bread (PNRA) said average associate wages rose 5% in the third quarter, both to "effectively compete for talent" and keep up with higher minimum wages. Panera CFO Michael Bufano went so far as to call the level of wage inflation "unprecedented" and noted that the company raised bakery prices 2.4% during the quarter to offset cost increases, according to a Seeking Alpha transcript.Second, average hourly wages have been rising at a 3.1% annual rate over the past six months and even faster over the past three months, 3.3%. In other words, monthly wage growth would have to slow to keep the annual rate of increase from rising significantly.Third, wage growth went through a slump in late 2015 and early 2016, so the weak comparison is likely to make the wage acceleration look even stronger than the underlying trend. In particularly, the three-month pace of wage growth fell to 1.9% in December 2015 and again in February 2016.Then, at the end of February, Wal-Mart (WMT) boosted wages by $1.5 billion, and Target (TGT) and Costco (COST) quickly followed with wage hikes of their own.IBD'S TAKE: The best stocks tend to have margins that are high relative to those of rivals and that are steady or growing, so look for companies that have the pricing power to withstand rising wages. For a primer on profit margins, read this Investor's Corner. IBD makes research easier with a proprietary SMR Rating that combines sales growth, profit margins and return on equity. Visit IBD Stock Checkup to see how your stocks rate.Markets took the news in stride on Friday that average hourly wages accelerated, with the 10-year Treasury yield and U.S. dollar index both losing ground. Yet it's hard to tell what's driving markets at the moment, in particular whether Donald Trump's revived presidential hopes are trumping other market-moving news.On Friday, Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank President Dennis Lockhart said he was "open to running the economy hot" to heal the labor market, but that's not yet a consensus view.Lockhart also said that "turmoil around the election" could interfere with December rate-hike plans.In September, when the Fed signaled that a December rate hike was coming, the median projection of policymakers was for two hikes in 2017. For now, markets aren't taking the Fed at its word. On Friday, the CME Group FedWatch tool showed markets pricing in a 71.5% chance of a December hike but just a 30.6% chance of a second hike through November 2017.RELATED:U.S. Added 161,000 Jobs, But Best Wage Gain Since 2009 Puts Pressure On Fed This Is The Best News About Wage Growth In A Year (But Markets Won't Love It)

The U.S. economy added 161,000 jobs in October, the Labor Department reported Friday, slightly below views, while wage gains ramped up.Economists had expected an increase of 173,000 jobs, though the prior two months were revised up by a combined 44,000.The unemployment rate dipped to 4.9%, as expected.But average hourly wages rose 0.4%, slightly stronger than expected. Hourly pay climbed 2.8% vs. a year earlier, the best since 2009, sending the 10-year Treasury yield higher.Odds of a December interest-rate hike, which had come down in recent days as markets fell and Donald Trump's odds of winning the White House rose, stood at 71.5% on Friday morning, according to the CME Group's FedWatch tool.This is the last employment report before Election Day on Nov. 8. The latest IBD/TIPP Presidential Election Tracking Poll has Trump and Hillary Clinton tied for a third straight day at 44%. There will be one more jobs report before the Fed's year-end meeting.The pace of job gains has moderated and is now running at 181,000 per month this year, a significant step down from monthly gains of 229,000 last year and 251,000 in 2014.Yet Federal Reserve policymakers have been expecting and even hoping for a moderation in job growth, so slower growth is unlikely to alter rate-hike plans. That's because they think the U.S. is close to full employment and don't want the labor market to overheat, forcing them to pick up the pace of rate hikes.That's why the pace of average hourly wage gains, which offers the clearest signal about how much labor market slack remains, is even more important than job growth in determining the Fed's rate-hike trajectory.Some anecdotal evidence has been pointing to a possible acceleration in wage gains from the muted pace that has defined the recovery.Starbucks (SBUX) on Oct. 3 gave a wage hike of at least 5% to every barista and manager at all of its U.S. stores.On an Oct. 26 conference call, Panera Bread (PNRA) said average associate wages rose 5% in the third quarter, both to "effectively compete for talent" and keep up with higher minimum wages. Panera CFO Michael Bufano went so far as to call the level of wage inflation "unprecedented" and noted that the company raised bakery prices 2.4% during the quarter to offset cost increases, according to a Seeking Alpha transcript.David Ownby, CFO of the Regal Entertainment (RGC) movie theater chain, said wages pressures were "at the high end of the range maybe of what we have experienced historically."Keith Cline, CEO of the La Quinta Holdings (LQ) hotel chain, spoke of "competitive wage inflation" to get the best people, noting that "labor in our industry is tight."IBD'S TAKE: The best stocks tend to have margins that are high relative to those of rivals and that are steady or growing, so look for companies that have the pricing power to withstand rising wages. For a primer on profit margins, read this Investor's Corner. IBD makes research easier with a proprietary SMR Rating that combines sales growth, profit margins and return on equity. Visit IBD Stock Checkup to see how your stocks rate.Peter Dameris, CEO of the On Assignment (ASGN) staffing firm, said there were "supply/demand imbalances in IT candidates," pointing to higher wages for the firm's consultants along with higher bill rates for the firm going forward, though outsourcing and offshoring offer alternative routes.Dunkin' Brands (DNKN) noted that franchisees had slowed down on the opening of Dunkin' Donuts stores, with minimum-wage increases and general election uncertainty among the reasons.Meanwhile, the National Federation of Independent Business said on Thursday that its survey of members showed a decline in small-business employment last month. "The combination of record uncertainty, rising labor costs and a shortage of qualified workers is depressing small-business job creation," said NFIB President and CEO Juanita Duggan.Job gains in October were focused on health care (31,000), professional and business services (43,000), finance (14,000) and insurance (8,000). The construction sector added 11,000 jobs, while manufacturing lost 9,000 and mining lost 2,000.RELATED:Minimum-Wage Hikes Slow Dunkin' Donuts Franchise GrowthThis Is The Best News About Wage Growth In A Year (But Markets Won't Love It)

Volume in the stock market today was slightly lower on the NYSE so far and accelerated on the Nasdaq.Online retail marketplace Alibaba (BABA) jumped as high as 104.10, moving back above the 50-day moving average. But shares have reversed lower, trading down 0.8% to 100.30.The stock rose sharply enough to retake its key 50-day moving average, keeping a rally from an early August breakout past an 85.10 cup with handle buy point intact.However, the market has been under intense selling pressure; on Tuesday, both the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 got hit with an 8th distribution day in recent weeks, as noted by Tuesday's Big Picture column.The China-based company reported fiscal Q2 quarterly results that topped the Street's views on the top and bottom lines. Earnings grew 39% and were roughly 15% above the consensus estimate. Revenue beat by 1%.Alibaba's cloud-computing revenue more than doubled sales and almost broke even, Bloomberg News reported. The stock holds a top-notch 99 Composite Rating from IBD Stock Checkup. The EPS Rating has been improving and is currently at 89, but following the latest results it's likely to go up.Stocks reporting after the close include Facebook (FB) and Qualcomm (QCOM).Economic data before the opening bell was mixed. That's still likely, but the odds have fallen in recent days.RELATED:Time Warner Lifts Views After Q3 BeatNext President May Toss Money Northrop's WayCloud Revenue Helps Alibaba Fiscal Q2 Results Soar

When the Federal Reserve held interest rates steady on June 15, among the stated reasons was concern about Brexit just a week ahead of the United Kingdom's fateful vote.Minutes of that meeting show that rate-setting committee members discussed the magnitude of the effect on financial markets from a U.K. vote to leave the European Union."It is a decision that could have consequences for economic and financial conditions in global financial markets," Federal Reserve Chairwoman Janet Yellen said in her post-meeting press conference. "If it does so, it could have consequences in turn for the U.S. economic outlook that would be a factor in deciding on the appropriate path of policy."The same might be said of the coming U.S. election. Economists and market analysts have estimated that a victory by Donald Trump could send major indexes down 5% to 12% and emerging market currencies, particularly Mexico's, could take a hit.(Trump and Hillary Clinton are tied at 44% in the latest IBD/TIPP Presidential Election Tracking Poll, after Clinton led by four points as of last Friday, when the FBI announced it was investigating new emails related to Clinton's email scandal.)Yet it's a safe bet that the Fed's decision Wednesday won't be guided by a candid discussion of the impact of a Trump victory. The GOP nominee has already criticized Yellen for letting politics determine the easier-than-expected path of policy. While there's ample reason to doubt that charge, contributions to Hillary Clinton's campaign by Lael Brainard, a leading dove and possible Clinton treasury secretary, have put the Fed in the political spotlight and risked undermining its reputation for independence.The Fed can avoid that uncomfortable conversation for now because there's never been a chance of a rate hike so close to next week's election. The real question is how a Trump victory could alter the chances of a hike in December. Odds have fallen from all-but-certain territory as Trump's electoral odds have improved since the FBI bombshell. The CME Group's FedWatch tool now shows 69.1% odds of a rate hike next month, down from roughly 85% last week.IBD'S TAKE: Stocks have fallen, gold prices have soared and the dollar has retreated in recent days, as the FBI reveals more evidence that stocks will fall if Trump wins.The 10-year Treasury yield and dollar both surged before Trump's rebound, as the Fed moved toward hiking rates even as other global central banks are still in easing mode for the foreseeable future. The rise in rates has been a modest negative for interest-rate sensitive sectors. Shares of Ford Motor (F) are close to a four-year low, while Home Depot (HD) shares are near an eight-month low.Meanwhile, the dollar's strengthening boded poorly for U.S. multinationals like General Electric (GE), which is close to an eight-month low after curbing its full-year earnings guidance as the dollar's rise cuts 6 cents per share from its bottom line.But now investors have bigger concerns, even as yields have come down and the dollar has lost a bit of the ground it gained on other major currencies last month. While the actual policies that Trump will implement as president are difficult to predict because he's unpredictable and they will require the backing of Congress, his threats of tariffs, walking away from Nafta and an immigration crackdown are making investors nervous.RELATED:FBI Reveals More Evidence That Stocks Will Fall If Trump WinsFed Keeps Rates Steady, Signals Slower Rate Hike Future

U.S. stocks were little changed Tuesday morning as the Federal Reserve began a two-day meeting.The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average each fell less than 0.1%. Volume in the stock market today was mixed — up on the NYSE and down on the Nasdaq.The Street expects the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates where they are but prepare the market for a hike in December. CME Group's FedWatch Tool sees a 7% chance for a rate hike Wednesday but a 78% probability for a rate hike of some kind in December.China grabbed the economic spotlight Tuesday morning as the world's second-largest economy reported three bullish pieces of data. A manufacturing gauge for large state-owned factories in China came in stronger than expected. The separate Caixin manufacturing gauge for midsize companies showed the best improvement in more than five years. A third gauge on services also rose.China stocks trading on U.S. exchanges, however, were not showing a strong reaction.In the U.S. market, blue chips were mixed. Chevron (CVX) led the stocks in the Dow. The integrated oil and gas stock rose 1% as it headed for its fifth gain in six sessions. Chevron trounced the consensus estimate on earnings Friday. The stock also features an annualized dividend yield of about 4%.The megacap oil play is edging closer to a potential breakout past a 107.68 entry in a flat base pattern.On the downside, Starbucks (SBUX) slouched toward its sixth loss in a row. The coffee chain will report quarterly results Thursday after the close. Analysts expect earnings to jump 28% to 55 cents a share. The stock has been declining for almost exactly one year. The big cap is now about 18% off its high of a year ago.In economic news, Redbook's gauge for retail sales rose 0.6%. The PMI manufacturing index increased from 51.5 in September to 53.4 in October. The ISM manufacturing index for October beat the Street's view for 51.6 with a 51.9 reading. But construction spending for September disappointed. The needle dipped 0.4% vs. views for a 0.6% increase.RELATED:GM, Fiat Chrysler U.S. Sales Fall Less Than ExpectedWhat Is The Flat Base Pattern, And How Does It Help You Make Money?

Stocks accelerated losses as they approached the midday mark Wednesday, with investors nervously awaiting release of the Federal Reserve's July 17 meeting.The minutes will be parsed for clues as to whether an interest-rate increase is on the table for the remainder of the year. The markets are skeptical.Traders in fed funds futures are pricing in an 18% chance of a rate increase at the Sept. 21 meeting, 19.3% at the Nov. 2 meeting and 42.6% odds at the Dec. 14 meeting, according to CME Group's FedWatch Tool.The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were down 0.4%, with the Nasdaq not far behind with a 0.3% deficit. Volume was running lower on the NYSE and higher on the Nasdaq compared with the same time Tuesday.Among IBD 50 stocks, 11 were higher and 39 were lower. The top performer was Chinese consumer loan operator Yirendai (YRD), up 7%. The volatile new issue has doubled in the last six weeks.IBD'S TAKE: Yirendai is the No. 1 stock in the consumer loan industry group. See why in IBD's Stock Checkup.Lowe's (LOW) gapped down and was trading 7% lower after it missed second-quarter estimates. It reported $1.31 a share vs. estimates of $1.41. Revenue came in at $18.26 billion compared with estimates of $18.45 billion.Target (TGT) gapped down and was trading 6% lower after it beat on estimates but lowered guidance.Home Depot (HD) was down 0.8% even though it received a price target increase from RBC Capital to 155 from 150.

U.S. stock indexes were lower near the noon hour Wednesday as investors awaited the release of the minutes from the July 27 Fed meeting at 2 p.m. ET. Cisco Systems (CSCO) lagged in the Dow ahead of its earnings report after the close, while Urban Outfitters (URBN) shined in an otherwise weak session for retail names.The market still isn't convinced the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates before the end of the year. The chances for a hike at the Sept. 21 meeting are currently around 18%, according to the CME. The odds for a hike at the December 14 are 46%.The Nasdaq composite lost 0.6%. If it closes lower today, it would be the Nasdaq's first two-session decline since the Brexit selloff in late June. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.4% each. Volume on the Nasdaq was tracking higher than Tuesday's level. Volume on the NYSE was on pace to be close to Tuesday.Oil lost a bit of ground even after the EIA reported a larger-than-expected decline in U.S. crude supplies. WTI crude oil for September eased 0.5% to $6.33 a barrel.Cisco fell 2%. Late Tuesday, CRN reported global job cuts could be as high as 14,000, or 20% of its global workforce.In the retail sector, Lowe's (LOW) and Target (TGT) fell sharply on earnings, but Urban Outfitters was a bright spot as profit and sales growth handily beat expectations. Shares soared 17%, clearing a cup-shaped base with a 34.87 entry. Analyst chatter was also positive.IBD'S TAKE: Buying a stock when it breaks out of a base can be a lucrative endeavor, especially when the market's in a confirmed uptrend. To learn more about recognizing bullish chart patterns, check out IBD University.Children's Place was near session lows but still rose 0.7% after the company reported better-than-expected sales and issued a bullish earnings outlook. The stock is still in buy range after reclaiming an 85.01 buy point Tuesday.Inside the IBD 50, China-based Yirendai (YRD), Cintas (CTAS) and Acacia Communications (ACIA) outperformed with gains of more than 1%.

Major stock indexes capped the week with solid gains Friday, helped by news of robust job growth in July.Merck (MRK) was the best percentage gainer in the Dow Jones industrial average, rising 10%, followed by financials like JPMorgan (JPM), American Express (AXP) and Goldman Sachs (GS), which showed gains of better than 2%.The Nasdaq composite rose 1.1% to a record close. The S&P 500 also marked an all-time closing high, up 0.9% and the Dow picked up 1%. Preliminary data showed volume on the Nasdaq coming in slightly higher than Thursday's levels. Volume on the NYSE was slightly lower.Merck was a beneficiary of bad news from Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY). The latter crashed 16% after its blockbuster drug Opdivo, already approved to treat some forms of cancer, did not meet its primary endpoint. Merck's competing drug Keytruda succeeded in a similar trial recently.IBD's super regional banks group was one of the day's top performers, rising more than 3%. Big gainers included SVB Financial (SIVB), KeyCorp (KEY) and Regions Financial (RF). Utilities lagged across the board.Meanwhile, the economy added 255,000 jobs in July, the second straight month of robust job growth.Despite the strong data, fed funds futures traders still aren't optimistic about a rate hike in September. According to the CME Group FedWatch tool, the odds for a September hike are currently around 18% but rise to 40% at the December meeting.Gold slumped and treasury yields jumped on the jobs data. Gold for December delivery settled at $1,344.40 an ounce, down $23 or 1.7%. The 10-year Treasury yield rose 7 basis points to 1.57%.In earnings news, Priceline (PCLN) has made several breakout attempts in recent months to no avail, but one came to fruition Friday on the heels of a strong earnings report. It gapped up over a 1,367.09 buy point, rising 4%.Leaderboard member Monster Beverage (MNST) added 2.5%. Earnings per share reported late Thursday missed expectations, but sales growth accelerated nicely from the prior quarter, rising 19% to $827.5 million.Monster was in buy range from a 154.06 buy point ahead of the results, but the stock is slightly extended now.IBD'S TAKE: Two stocks in Monster's industry group, Beverages-Non-Alcoholic, have higher Composite Ratings than Monster. See who they are with IBD Stock Checkup.

The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged Wednesday afternoon at the end of its two-day policy meeting. Policymakers said "near-term risks" to the economy have faded, but investors generally saw the central bank in no rush to raise rates.Key points from the FOMC policy statement:Stocks closed mixed on Wednesday, little changed from before the Fed announcement at 2 p.m. The Nasdaq rose 0.6% on the stock market today, fueled by a soaring Apple (AAPL) after its late Tuesday earnings report. The Dow Jones industrial average closed  down less than 2 points while the S&P 500 dipped 0.1%. In addition to Apple's lift, Boeing (BA) and Facebook (FB) also provided big-cap boosts, but oil prices below $42 a barrel pressured energy stocks. Boeing beat before the opening bell, while Facebook reported blowout earnings -- up 94% -- after the closing bell.The S&P 500 and Dow industrials have been hitting record highs, rebounding strongly from a post-Brexit vote sell-off. The 10-year Treasury yield fell to 1.50% and the dollar pulled back.IBD'S TAKE: Gold-related stocks are rallying as the go-slow Fed and weak dollar boost bullion. Which gold miners are up? Click here.The Fed statement was a tiny step toward an eventual rate hike. But, if anything, investors pushed back expectations of a rate hike. According to the CME Group FedWatch Tool, there is now a 43% chance of a hike by the December meeting, the first time a move is seen as a serious possibility. Before the Fed announcement, it was 50-50.  A rate hike isn't actually seen as likely until next May.Investors see less than a 20% chance of a hike at the September or November meetings.Kansas City Fed President Esther George was the lone dissenter, favoring a quarter-point rate hike.

Stock indexes advanced quietly Friday, as attention shifted to looming economic news and upcoming quarterly reports. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each rose 0.5%, while the Dow added 0.3%. The IBD 50 rose 0.9%. The Dow Jones utility average popped 1.4%, though it was nearly flat for the week. Volume fell across the board. With the indexes playing a game of…

The consumer is back. So are jobs. Services prices are increasing at the fastest pace in more than seven years. Even industrial production, the economy's weakest link, is back on the rise. Stocks have shrugged off Brexit and are trading at record highs.What more does the Federal Reserve need to resume nudging up interest rates from close to zero?June sales surged 3.9% at building material and garden stores like Home Depot (HD) and Lowe's (LOW), the Commerce Department said Friday. Sales from nonstore retailers led by Amazon (AMZN) continued to impress, rising 1.1% on the month and 14.2% from a year ago. The latter was the strongest gain in a decade.Overall, retail sales rose 0.6%, triple the estimated gain. Auto sales edged up 0.1%, amid a down month for General Motors (GM) and Toyota (TM), but gains at Ford (F) and Fiat Chrysler (FCAU).Core retail sales, excluding frequently volatile auto, gas and building material sales, rose 0.5% for a second straight month, following a 1.1% gain in April.The economy likely grew at a 2.75% annual rate in the second quarter, propelled by a gain of at least 4% in real consumer spending, says Harm Bandholz, chief U.S. economist at UniCredit Research.Yet he expects the Fed to stay on hold through the U.S. presidential election, then hike its key interest rate a quarter-point in December. Markets don't see another rate hike until March 2017, according to the CME Group FedWatch tool.But markets have been on a roller-coaster ride since they woke up after the U.K. Brexit vote results came in on June 23. Stocks initially tumbled, but the S&P 500 and Dow industrials hit all-time highs this week. After falling to a historic low of 1.34% before last week's June employment report, the 10-year Treasury yield has bounced back to 1.59%. That jobs report, showing a 287,000 increase in payrolls, erased concerns caused by the negligible May payroll gain.For now, yields may keep rising without a Fed hike because markets might start to price in a faster pace of rate increases in 2017 and 2018.Fed policymakers have signaled that they want time to assess the impact of the U.K. voting to leave the European Union. Initial indications are that the vote will hurt the U.K. but shouldn't be much of a negative for the U.S., which got a short-term boost from lower interest rates that fueled a surge of mortgage refinancing.While eurozone economies are expected to face a drag from weaker trade with the U.K., the real wild card is whether the political backlash that spurred the Brexit vote spreads to other parts of Europe, especially Italy. The next shoe to drop could come in October, when Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's package of constitutional reforms meant to overcome gridlock faces a referendum.If Renzi's vote fails, he'll be on the way out, and the vacuum could put the anti-EU Five Star Movement in the driver's seat. But all that could take a year or more to play out, and the odds of Italy ever abandoning the euro are slim.Bottom line, European politics are unlikely to provide the Fed much of an excuse to stay on the sideline for long, particularly if core inflation continues to pick up.The core CPI, excluding food and energy, rose 0.2% in June and 2.3% from a year ago. The annual gain matched the biggest increase since September 2008.Services inflation, excluding energy services, rose 3.2% from a year ago in June, also matching May's gain for the biggest since September 2008.The Fed has set a 2% inflation target. But the central bank's preferred price gauge, the PCE deflator in the income and spending report, showed only a 1.6% annual gain as of May.Food prices fell 0.1% in June, as the price of food consumed at home fell 0.3% and the food away from home rose 0.2%. Now, food at home costs 1.3% less than a year ago, while food away from home is up 2.6%. That pricing differential may be among the reasons why fast-food chains like McDonald's (MCD) and Wendy's (WEN) have a seen a slowdown.Sales at food services and drinking places fell 0.3% in May, one of the softest spots in an otherwise solid retail report.Meanwhile, industrial production perked up 0.6% in June, the best gain in 11 months. Manufacturing output rose 0.4%, mining 0.2% and utilities 2.4%. That's the first time all year that each of the three categories saw an increase.Overnight, China said the world's No. 2 economy expanded 6.7% in the second quarter vs. a year earlier, matching Q1's pace. Economists had expected a dip to 6.6%. Meanwhile, separate June reports on industrial production, retail sales and bank loans all showed accelerating growth, topping forecasts.

The U.S. economy saw job growth rebound in June as payrolls surged by 287,000, following May's downwardly revised 11,000 gain.Average hourly earnings edged up 2 cents to $25.61, up 2.6% from a year ago, which is the biggest annual gain in 2016 and tied for the best of the recovery.Over the past three months, job gains have averaged 147,000, which marks a clear slowdown from the 196,000-per-month gain in the first quarter and 229,000 average monthly gain in 2015.Still, along with the upward trend in wage gains, the more moderate pace of job growth likely would have been fast enough for the Federal Reserve to start hiking rates again soon, but Brexit will likely keep policymakers on the cautious side.While major stock indexes got a nice lift from the encouraging jobs report, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq both up over 1% in the morning, the 10-year Treasury yield has barely budged from the record lows set earlier in the week.IBD'S TAKE: Stocks rose solidly Friday on the jobs report. Investors are cheering the stronger hiring, but without fears that it will trigger a near-term rate hike due to Brexit.According to the CME Group FedWatch tool, markets don't expect any rate hikes through at least June 2017, but some economists find that hard to believe."Some moderation in employment dynamics was expected as the U.S. economy has basically reached full employment, and the trend growth in the labor force is somewhere between 100,000 and 125,000," wrote Harm Bandholz, chief U.S. economist at UniCredit Research.In other words, employment growth above 125,000 will reduce what little labor slack is left, in his view. Bandholz expects a rate hike at the end of 2016.Wells Fargo Securities economists are on the same page: "The continued rise in payrolls along with the very modest rise in average hourly earnings will keep (Fed) policy tilted toward another fed funds rate increase this year, but we believe it is unlikely to come before the election," wrote John Silvia and Sarah House.The rebound in job growth came as the leisure and hospitality sector added 59,000 jobs, health care 39,000, information industries 44,000 and retail 30,000.The goods-producing sector added 9,000 jobs, but that came after four months of declines. In June, mining industries shed 6,400 jobs, while construction employment was flat and factories added 14,000 workers.The jobless rate rose to 4.9% from 4.7% in May, as 414,000 people streamed back into the labor force, while employment rose by 67,000, according to the household survey that tends to be more volatile than the more closely watched establishment survey.The Verizon Communications (VZ) strike had cut May employment by as much as 35,000, and its resolution provided a comparable boost to the June payrolls.Many analysts had expected an upward revision to May's figures. Bandolz noted that imperfect seasonal adjustments to the data by the Labor Department likely explain a big part of May's weakness and June's strength.

The unexpected U.K. vote to leave the European Union has predictably set off a flight to safety, sinking global equity markets and Treasury yields, while boosting the value of the dollar.The immediate consequences are the opposite of what the weak global economy needed and have just put further pressure on the Federal Reserve and other central banks that were already running low on firepower.While there's much uncertainty about how the EU's second-largest economy will disentangle itself from the economic and political union, and while the process will play out over two years or more, economists are now forecasting a brief U.K. recession in 2017.Yet the U.K. only accounts for about 2.4% of global GDP, meaning that even a moderate recession is something the rest of the world should be able to take in stride. So why would global markets come unglued over Brexit? The short answer is that there's a lot more at stake than just U.K. GDP."It is not an exaggeration to suggest a new world order will need to be defined, and further changes to the EU's composition clearly cannot be ruled out," wrote Alastair George, chief strategist at Edison Investment Research. "This is a momentous day for the U.K., but also for the EU -- investors simply can no longer make the assumption that the status quo will always prevail."The Brexit vote will provoke "a crisis of confidence in the whole (European) integration project," wrote Daniela Schwarzer of the German Marshall Fund of the U.S. "Market pressure may be particularly high on the southern periphery where sovereign debt is reaching unsustainable levels and instabilities in the banking sector persist. The situation is particularly fragile as Portugal, Spain, Italy and France all have weak leaders or face political instability."Still, Schwarzer writes, there is an opportunity for France and Germany to offer reforms in short order that address "what people seem to worry most about: security, welfare and migration."For now, though, uncertainty about the future of Europe and concern about the disruption of trade are likely to weigh on investment and growth. IHS Global Insight, which had been forecasting 1.5% GDP growth in Germany in 2017, now sees growth of 0.4% to 0.9%.U.S. economic growth also may take a small hit. A stronger dollar after Brexit will hurt the earnings of U.S. multinationals, make domestic manufacturing less competitive and dampen capital investment. Global banks and travel-related stocks, such as JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C), American Airlines (AAL), Priceline (PCLN) and United Airlines (UAL) were among Friday's biggest losers.The dollar's rise also could trigger bigger problems in emerging markets, especially China, which could come under further pressure to ease its currency peg as the country tries to keep its economy from slowing too much. Slower global growth also will be a negative for commodities prices.Federal Reserve policymakers were divided earlier this month between those who wanted to raise rates one more time in 2016 and those who favored two hikes. Now, Fed rate hikes appear to be off the table for the foreseeable future, after a lone hike in December 2015The CME Group's FedWatch tool says markets are pricing just a 22% chance of another rate hike by the policy meeting next Feb. 1.The Fed released the following statement Friday morning: "The Federal Reserve is carefully monitoring developments in global financial markets, in cooperation with other central banks, following the results of the U.K. referendum on membership in the European Union."The Federal Reserve is prepared to provide dollar liquidity through its existing swap lines with central banks, as necessary, to address pressures in global funding markets, which could have adverse implications for the U.S. economy," it said.The 10-year Treasury yield fell 17 basis points to 1.57%, hitting a four-year low intraday, as prices for the safe haven asset climbed. In the short term, this should be a positive for the housing sector, for consumers who refinance their homes and for auto purchases.As far as actually boosting growth, it's not clear that the extraordinary measures already tried by the Fed, the Bank of England, the European Central Bank and the Bank of Japan can make much more of a difference. The ECB and BOJ continue to conduct asset purchases, known as quantitative easing, and more recently have tried negative rates, with little or nothing to show for it."Monetary policy ... may have become counterproductive at the margin," wrote Andrew Bell, the chief executive of Witan Investment Trust in London. "The next phase will need to create a source of demand" via fiscal policy.Thomas Simons, senior money market economist at Jefferies Fixed Income, told IBD that Brexit will increase the urgency of central bank policy that puts money in the hands of consumers, rather than quantitative easing that reduces borrowing costs but requires an appetite for lending to work.While the U.S. economy remains in relatively good shape because it is domestically fueled and services-oriented, he thinks the Bank of Japan is going to have to lead the way in a so-called helicopter drop: "transfer cash directly to the treasury, then the treasury would have a large amount of fuel" to propel the economy out of its funk.

The Federal Reserve, while holding rates steady as expected on Wednesday, took a dovish turn but also signaled that markets might still be too complacent about the chances for rate hikes later in the year.While a hike at the next meeting July 27 is very much of a long shot, individual members’ projections for future policy still point to two hikes this year. However, six Fed officials now see just one hike this year, vs. just one official back in March. Eleven still see at least two hikes this year. Not all of those 17 officials are voting members this year.The median forecast among policymakers is for a federal funds rate target of 1.6% at the end of 2017 and 2.4% at the end of 2018, down from a respective projections of 1.9% and 3.0% in March.But markets are no longer pricing in any tightening at all this year, according to the CME Group’s FedWatch tool, with a 48% chance at the February meeting next year.Stocks initially held onto their modest gains from before the Fed announcement, but turned negative shortly before the market close. The S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow industrials all closed 0.2%.The 10-year Treasury yield fell after the Fed meeting to 1.59%, closing at the lowest levels since 2012. The dollar eased.Given the recently poor track record of Fed projections, which had penciled in four 2016 rate hikes last December, investors may take the latest batch of forecasts with a grain of salt. Further, policy uncertainty is especially high, with the upcoming Brexit vote deciding whether the U.K. will leave the European Union, which could trigger a bout of investor risk-aversion.Fed Chair Janet Yellen said in a post-meeting press conference that the Brexit vote due for later this month played a factor in the decision to leave rates unchanged, and its outcome could impact policy in the months ahead.The Fed statement noted that labor market gains appear to have slowed in recent months, even as economic growth has picked up.Mixed recent data suggest the Fed's "cautious approach" to normalizing rates is appropriate, Yellen said. She highlighted weak business investment, even outside the energy sector, as an unexpected and persistent economic drag.Treasury yields have been sinking along with market expectations for future rate hikes since May’s employment report showed just 25,000 private-sector jobs were added last month. Policymakers and investors will be awaiting further data to see if job creation has slowed markedly, or whether the report was a one-month blip.Yellen is seen as among the most dovish Fed policy committee members. In a June 3 speech, following the weak jobs report, she characterized current rate levels as only “modestly accommodative.” In the same speech, she downgraded her sense of whether and when further rate hikes would be appropriate from “probably in the coming months” to “probably.” She also raised a possibility that slower hiring in April and May would prove to be “a harbinger of a persistent slowdown in the broader economy.”The Fed projections show that more members have come around to her viewpoint, though she doesn't yet hold sway.Members now see 2.0% growth in 2016, 2017 and 2018, trimming estimates of 2.2% this year and 2.1% next. The slower trajectory of expected rate hikes comes despite modestly higher-than-expected inflation, with members seeing core inflation of 1.7% this year, up from a 1.6% forecast in March.
